editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: King Iohn AND MATILDA, A TRAGEDY. As it was Acted with great Applauſe by her Majesties Servants at the Cock-pit in Drury-lane.
LONDON, Printed for Andrew Pennycuicke, in the Year 1655.

div.head: The Names of the Perſons in the Play, And of the Actors that firſt Acted it on the Stage, and often before their Majesties.

list.label: King John,
Fitzwater,
list.item: M. Perkins Whoſe action gave Grace to the Play.
list.label: Old Lord Bruce,
Young Bruce,
Cheſter,
Oxford,
Leister,
Hubert,
Pandolph,
Brand,
list.item: M. Shirelock, who performed excellently well.

list.head: Other Lords and Gentlemen, Attendants on the King.

div.head: To the knowing Reader.
div.p: A Good Reader, helps to make a Book; a bad injuries it: The Author of this, had no mind to be a man in Print; nor tooke he any care for a Sculpture, to illuſtrate the Frontiſ-piece by crowning himſelfe with Laurel: Neither did he write his owne Encomiums, and (to prejudicate the ſimple) ſay his friends forc'd them upon him; they may help to ſell the Book, not better the Matter. And ſince this Tragedy is come to tell its own tale, and to ſpeak for it ſelf, he wil he glad to know it able to ca • ry its own commendation; And (being an Infant, newly deliver'd to the world from the wombe of the Preſs) he hopes the knowing Reader will rather Crown it by his Candor, then kill it in the Cradle.

div.head: To the Right Honourable, Mountague Berty, Earle of Lindſey, Lord Willougbby to Ereſby &c.
div.p: YOu are no ſtranger to things of this nature, and therefore the Dedication will not ſtartle you; ſuch there are (my Lord) whoſe ſoules are confin'd to their Chinck, and theſe looke ſquint-ey'd upon a Dedication, becauſe they feare there is a Spirit in't will ſeparate them: But my Lord, your Nobleneſſe to learning, and wit raiſeth your estimate to ſo high an accompt among knowing men, thi • from thence I have derived this boldneſſe, which I hope is pardonable not onely for that your juſtice calls upon me for a duty I long ſince owed your Honour, but alſo in regard the Thing preſented is no ſleight Piece, but ſuch (my Lord) at I preſume will accord with your judgement and likeing: It paſt the Stage with generall Applauſe (my ſelfe being the laſt that that Acted Matilda in it) and ſince through the abſurdity of times, it hath laine obſcured. My Lord, though it doth not appeare in it's ancient and full glory, yet it comes drest; firſt, with an humble regard to your Honour, and then a confidence of it's naked worth, but both it and my ſelfe, are willingly ſubjected unto your Honours ſentence, which I hope will not be too heavy, eſpecially upon

div.head: Actus 1. Scoena 1.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: THey will not come?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: They will not.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: They had been better—
What was their anſwer?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Thus ſaid Fitzwater, father of the faction,
That was Generall for the Barrons againſt your Majeſtie:
Tell John,

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: John!

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: That was his Epithite;
(Alledging how you ſtood at Rome, put from
Your Kingly office.) Tell John, quoth he, (and frown'd)
That here at Baynards Caſtle, we intend
A ſettled ſtay for private reformations.
Of conceiv'd injuries, which by the peace
The King made with us, were not throughly ſearch'd,
But like green wounds, clos'd with too ſwift a ſalve,
(Upon your private ends) are with more danger
Doubts and diſtracted difficulties again
Broke forth; but having drawn them to a head,
They would ſend them to you to be ratified,
And then give their attendance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This is brave;
Who was there elſe?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Richmond, imperious Leiſter, and old Bruce.
(The ſecond in this revolt,) who ſent the ſame return.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A • neſt of Rebels; to try the truth of theſe fine floriſhes,
You with Lord Mowbray, poſt unto Guilford,
And being there, (pretending a viſite unto Bruces Lady,)
Wind into obſervation of the Caſtle ſo from her,
(The engine upon which theſe factions move,)
Diſcover the intent of their diſignes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Sure ſir, the Lady is noble; but your Majeſties
Injunction ſhall be obey'd.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This not onely advantages
Our meeting with Fitzwaters Daughter,
(O how the thought) ſtartles my blood)
But likewiſe furthers our reſolv'd proceedings:
Cheſter the news?

sp.speaker: Cheſt.
sp.l: Conceal your ſelfe ſir,
I have trapt her with a ſnare.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Agen, then I ſhall ſee he • —

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You told me Cheſter
That the Queen did earneſtly requeſt my attendance:
You ſaid ſhe was here i'th Garden,
But it ſeems you were miſ-inform'd.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Excellent innocence how art thou trapt!
I muſt attend the King; pleaſe you walk Madam
But towards the Grove, I was told the Queen and Ladies
Retyred there for ſhade.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I ſhall,

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: And I muſt vaniſh

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh heaven, the King!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thy friend.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Falſe Cheſter!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Fair Matilda,
Miſtreſſe of youth and beauty, ſweet as a ſpring,
And comely as the holy ſhining Prieſt
Deckt in his glorious ſacerdotall veſtment;
Yet heare the paſſions of a love ſick Prince,
And crown thy too too cruell heart with pitty.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yet let fall your too too paſſionate plea • ings,
And crown your royall heart with excellent reaſon.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: The Queen will heare you.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Speak but a word that—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: That may ſound like ſomething,
That may but buſie my ſtrong labouring heart,
With hope that thou wilt grant, and every morning
I will walk forth and watch the early Lark,
And at her ſweeteſt note I will proteſt,
Matilda ſpake a word was like that note.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh how you tempt: remember pray your vows
To my betroth'd Earl Robert Huntington;
Did you not wiſh juſt as the poyſon toucht
His manly heart, i • ever you again
Laid battery to the fair fort of my unvanquiſh'd
Vertue, your death might be like his untimely,
And be poyſon'd. Oh take heed ſir,
Saints ſtand upon heavens ſilver battlements,
When Kings make vows, and lay their
Liſtening ears to Princes Proteſtations.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: So did Matilda ſwear to live and die a maid,
At which fair Nature like a Snail ſhrunck back,
As loath to hear from one ſo fair, ſo foul
A wound: my vow was vain, made without
Recollection of my reaſon; and yours, Oh madneſſe!
Maids have ſure forſworne ſuch vowes:
For Huntington, he like a heap of ſummers
Duſt into his Grave is ſwept; and bad vows
Still are better broke then kept.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Alas great ſir, your Queen you cannot make me;
What is it then inſtructs your tongue? Oh ſir!
In things not right,
Luſt is but loves well languag'd hypocrite.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Words ſhall convert to deeds then; I am the King.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Doe but touch me,
And as I graſpe ſteel in my trembling hand,
sp.stage: Offers violence, ſhe drawes a knife.
sp.l: So ſure the King ſhall ſee Matilda fall
A ſacrifice to vertue.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Cruell Maid,
Crueller then the Kid that eanes her young
On the rough boſome of a ragged flint:
Go get thee to the woods, for thou art wild
As flame, or winter; where ſo e're thou walk'ſt
May wild winds chide thee, and the reeling Trees
Like a confus'd fall of many waters
Rail on thy rudeneſs; may the birds that build
Among the wanton branches, ſtead of teaching
Notes to their young, ſing ſomething like thy niceneſs:
And laſtly, may the Brooks when thou ſhalt lie
And caſt a pair of cruell buſie eyes
Upon their ſubtill ſlydings, may the water,
The troubled image of my paſſions war
With the ſtones, the matter of thy heart, that thou maiſt learn
Thy hardneſſe and my ſufferings to diſcern;
And ſo whilſt I (if it be poſſible) ſtudy to forget you,
May beaſts, and bird • , and brooks, and trees, and wind,
Hear me, and call Matilda too unkind.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ile unto Baynards Caſtle to my father,
Oh ſhe had a violent need of Caſtles, where a King
Layes ſuch violent ſeige; but Oh truth,
Thou art (whilſt tenant in a noble breſt,)
A crown of Chriſtall in an Ivory cheſt.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Shall I be dazled with effeminate darings?

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: With a womans ward, a knife too.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Here I left her.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: But here ſhe is not now ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh Cheſter run, run as thou lov'ſt my peace,
Feather thy feet with lovers wiſhes, let but my deſires
Dwel in thy eyes, thou'lt find her, were ſhe compaſt
With a Cimerian miſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I will do my beſt ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thy beſt; do every thing, do any thing,
Do all things that may find her; whether Love
Leads thy dark Labyrinth; cannot Kings be free
From thy impetuous buffets? I have de •• 'd
A heardned heart, obdurate to thy ſhafts,
And ſome times am ſo, when in the very minute
Calling to mind Matilda's tears, like drops
Continued upon marble, they pierce through,
And I am ſoft again. Haſt found her?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No ſir, ſhe is by this in Baynards Caſtle,
Where her Father and the Lords—

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Command our Barge, wee'l after her like lightning:
We muſt have pledges Cheſter for their faiths; if they refuſe,
Thunder ſhall meet with thunder, and each eye
Shall ſee ſtrange Comets in this troubled skie.

div.stage: Enter Fitzwater, old Bruiſe, young Bruiſe, Richmond and Leiſter, as in Baynards Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: My noble Lords, and honourable friends,
Not to particularlize (what need plain dealing
Be apparelled in particulars?) to a ſhort ſupper,
Or a poor pittance rather, ye are all
Heartily welcome, very heartily, I muſt tell truth ſtill.

sp.speaker: O Br.
sp.l: Brother we thank you.

sp.speaker: Eitz.
sp.l: I would we had my ſiſter your wife, at Guilford with us.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Where are the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Comfo • ting Matilda, ſad return'd from Court.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Betraid by Cheſter, and again eſcap'd
Like a chaſte Dove out of the fowlers Net,
The luſtfull King.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Oh John, John, wilt thou never
Leave thy wags tricks? but let it paſſe, tis beſt
Becauſe indeed tis paſt.

sp.speaker: Leíſ.
sp.l: I wonder how he receiv'd our reſolv'd anſwer.

sp.speaker: Y B • u.
sp.l: No matter how, he's like to have no other;
Now by my blood, you vext my very ſoul
That you ſ • nt any.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: Sonne, have a tamer ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Y Bru.
sp.l: Yes, and like horſes,
Be held by'th noſe by frivilous reſpect,
Whilſt he caſts Copperis into our ſores, and ſearches
Paſt honours patience.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Nephew, Nephew, hear me,
Lets bear a little; faith he is the King,
And though at Rome he does ſtand interdicted,
Yet now and then takes a good ſtart or two
Towards regularity, till the fit comes on him;
And for your neat horſe ſimile obſerve me,
Richmond and you are young men, we three old,
But not too old to tell truth; the horſe that will not
Stand till and endure ſearching, how e're in ſummer
With warmth and paſture, he may ſtrike at flies,
And play the wanton in a wealthy meadow,
For all his ſummer paſtime, yet tis ſaid,
Winter will leave him but a lean ſcal'd jade;
Come, come, y'ar fooles, y'ar fooles.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Well let us—bear then.

sp.speaker: Y Bru.
sp.l: • et us? Oh my blood!
Beſides, our in uries in his breach of promiſe,
He made by ſtains and publique grievances,
How in the flames of his adulterate heart
Purſues he my chaſte Couſin, by flights gets her
Within his tallon, and but this afternoon,
(Had not her friendly knife enfranchis'd her)
Even in the face of he • ven, in his own Garden
He would have raviſh'd her.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: Bro • her, we are bound in honour not to bear it.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Let him know our griefs, and if—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, well, with iſs and ands
Mad men leave Rocks, and leap into the Sands;
But ſomething ſhall be thought on.

sp.speaker: Rich •
sp.l: The King attended
Onely with the Earle of Cheſter, Oxford, and ſome
Other Gentlement, is new landed on the Stairs.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: The King!

sp.speaker: Y Bru.
sp.l: Shut the ſtairs Gate.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Twere better Gate and ſtairs
Were floating through bridg; we are ſafe my cholerick couſin,
As in a Sanctuary; tis enough
(A man would think,) to ſee a great Prince thus,
Cauſe wee'd not go to him, to come to us,
sp.stage: Ent. King, Oxford, Cheſter. and other Lords
sp.l: Indeed, indeed, you ſpeak unkindly.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Behold great Lords,
The Cedars of the Kingdome, how the King
(A ſhrub) ſhrincks out of majeſtie.
And comes to you; here's a fine Conventicle,
Are ye blowing up new ſires? and muſt Fitz • waters
(Plain-breaſted as his unaffected habite,)
Be Generall again, again be call'd
The Marſhall of Heavens Army and the Churches?
Are you Planet ſt uck • you cannot talke.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Your pardon ſir,
I led the Barrons, but twas when they could not chooſe
But chooſe a leader, and then me they choſe;
And why ſo think ye? they all lov'd your Grace,
And grieve, grieve very heartily, I tell you,
To ſee you by ſome ſtate mice ſo miſled:
This ſtate mice that nibble ſo upon the Lands impaired freedom
That would not ſo play in the Lyons eare,
But that by tickling him themſelves to advantage;
This troubl'd us, and griev'd the body Politique,
And this we ſought to mend; I tell truth John, I,
We are thy friends John, and if ye take from friendſhip
The liberty of modeſt admonition,
Ye leave no mark whereby to diſtinguiſh it
From the fawning paſſion of a Dog-baſe flattery;
If I ſpeak plain, this truth be my deſence,
A good mans comſort is his Conſcience:
And ſo much for plain Robin.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Fitzwater, Bruce, Richmond, and ſtubborn Leiſter,
This is the laſt of our admonitions,
Either lay by thoſe Arms, thoſe lawleſſe arms,
Which you have liſted 'gainſt your Lord the King,
And give ſuch pledges as we ſhall accept
For ſettling of your loyalties, or here
By the abuſed ſufferings of a King,
And by the unkind ſcars with which you have
Deform'd the face of England; miſery
Shall over take you in a ſhape ſhall fright
The Iron heart of faction, and the King
Shall come no more acquainted with compaſſion,
But call the bloodieſt ends a righteous vengeance.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: I will not leave mine arms,
Nor break my word to you,
Unleſſe provok'd, and juſtly; you have my faith,
If you miſlike that pledge—

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: And I reply that I can ſpare no nother.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: D'ce hear ſir?

sp.speaker: O Bru.
sp.l: Already we have pawn'd the now ſcorn'd gage
Of our afflicted honours, which refus'd
Flies back again, and ſo we ſtand diſcharg'd.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: King John, King John,
Perform but the ſeal'd Covenants you are fled from,
The Charter running thus, given by our hand
The ſeventeenth day of June, and in the year
215 (the whole Realm being ſworn to't,)
And ſix and twenty Peers and Barrons ſworn
To the execution (who if you fail) are perjur'd
Do this, and like a plat of Oſier wands
We ſhall bow any way, and you ſhall work us
Into what faſhion you ſhall fancy; but
if you be melancholly, love-ſick John,
Or Lyon, unyoak'd Heifer, head-ſtrong John,
(As in the matter of the Loſſe of Normandie,
When Anjou, Brittain, Main, Poictou, and Turwin,
Were deliver'd up to Philip) you'l find your friends
Not facile Willowes, but abrupt brambles,
Whoſe intricate irregularity
Whilſt you ſhall go about to rectifie,
They'l prick your fingers, and with unkind ſcratches,
Expoſe you to a late deplor'd experience:
Come, come, know this, when love in our ſide ſings,
The unkindeſt wounds are thoſe we take from Kings;
I am plain Robin.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A down right Rebell.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Rebell!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: So are ye all.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Rebells!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Traytors.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Traytors!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Rebels and Traytors; Cheſter, Oxford, Gentlemen,
Stand on your guards, there's danger in the room.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: You ate too paſſionate, perform with us,
You ſhall walk over us, if not, we ſtand
Our injur'd Countries Juſticers.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Proud boaſter.
This night ſhall raiſe a ſtorme: Brav'd? with you Bruce
We will begin; and yet he is the Brother
Unto Matilda's Father, but his inſolence,
Oh love; a little while let revenge raigne,
This night ſhall beget paſſages ſhall prove
Your King a Lyon (vext) as (pleas'd) a Dove.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Lights for the King; there Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: What will you do? a tempeſt curl'd his forehead
Into the faſhion of an angry Ocean,
Made wild with winds.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: We muſt reſolve on ſomething.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: And ſuddenly, for in his executions
He is ſwift as lightning, ayr is not more light.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Pandulph the Popes ſtern Legate, tis divulg'd,
Is againe come over from the Pope, to proffer
The King his readmiſſion into the Church,
And take off his ſix years interdiction
Upon ſome propoſitions yet conceal'd,
And this may buſie the King yet.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: This? the Greyhound
Is not more eager at his flying game,
Then I know King John is in his paſſions
Gf love or anger.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: Why Brother, is this a time to ſtudy?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Troth I was thinking of—ſtay, ſtay, I hav't,
I was thinking brother Bruce,—now tis gone again,
And farewell it, lets ply our buſineſſe now:
If you mark't, he ſaid he would begin with you;
I Would have you to night (ſtay not for the Sun,
Which ſure will riſe bluſhing at this nights brawling)
Do you and Richmond, with ſome ſcore of men
Poſt to your houſe, tis but an hours riding,
And ſomething more; there fortifie your ſelves,
Your Ladie, and your pretty little Sonnne,
Poor knave he dreams not of theſe Thunderbolts:
You my young mad cap, with your Cuz my daughter,
Shall unto Hartford Caſtle, ſhe is the brand
I feare will fire our Troy; Leiſter and I
Will gather Powers, and thither after you;
You two for Guilford, you two for Hartford,
And we two, wheither waſt we two muſt go?

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Go? we two muſt ſtay i'th City.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Paſſion of me, where was my memory;
But come, come, when Kings our Dials retrograde do run,
We leave to look on them, and go by'th Sun:
Lights, lights, good Gentlemen:

div.stage: Enter Queene, Lady, Bruce, and Hubert.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Good Lady take not on ſo, Oxford ſayes all
Is very well at London.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, very well;
Why then follow'd he your Grace with a Troop of horſe,
A band of men? why hath he ſeizd the Caſtle,
Caſhierd my Servants? Oh Madam can it be,
Your Grace (the Alter where I ever paid
A Subjects devout Love,) ſhould by a ſlight,
a fained accidentall viſite make,
An entrance for hoſtility and terror.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hubert, redeem you in this Ladies faith,
And relate the truth.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Only upon mine honour
Was I ſent to ſeize this Ladies young Son George,
As a pledge to'th King for her Lords loyalty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No Hubert, my Son is far enough from thee,
Thou fatall keeper of poor Boys.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You mean
Concerning Arthur, the unfortunate Sonne
Of Jeffery Plantaganet; Oh mad rumour!
Who would truſt thee but with ſo much reputation
An honeſt begger boaſts of?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: In that beleeve me Madam, report hath wronged him,
Which I can witneſſe Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The King come to,
Oh my ſweet George, my joy; what wilt thou do?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: All is to our deſire; where's Bruces Sonne?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Convey'd to Wales ſhe affirms Sir.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Where thou ſhalt never ſee him John.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Good Madam,
Wee'l ſpeak with you anon, Queene Iſabell,
Thou muſt be ſtill an agent to ſecure
Me and my Kingdome, ſtraight with the Earl of Cheſter;
Poſt thou to Hartford Caſtle, whither we are certifi'd
Young Bruce is fled with old Fitzwaters daughter,
Try if by fair means thou canſt win her to
Attend on thee at Court; if we have not her
A pledge, (as this) for her Fathers faith, we ſtand
The food of faction, get her any way;
If ſhe deny, Cheſter with forces ready,
Of from the Caſtle, ſhall give them fierce aſſault,
And force them paſt entreaties; go my love
And play the Amazon, with her ſurpriſall,
Secure a Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: This craves haſt and care; come noble Cheſter
You ſhall along; but good my Lord forget not
That Ladies kindneſſe to me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh my ſweet.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: What a fine thing he makes the Queen; Oh luſt,
With what ſmooth craft thou creeptſt to things unjuſt.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh my Matilda, if power or policy
may get thee once more in theſe arms, I will hazard
Even to a Kingdom for thee; come Madam fear not
I wear no frowns, I am all mirth, lets ſee your pretty Son.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I fear your mirth is like the Porpoiſt paſtimes,
My Son hath been in Wales this moneth.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hubert, ſee the Gates lock'd, a guard upon the Walls,
Whilſt we take ſome to ſearch.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where will you ſearch King John?
For heavens ſake do not ſearch.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Nay and't be come to that.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let me go,
In theſe proceedings the Kings ſafety reſts,
The Lyon muſt not bend to baſer breaſts.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Heaven to thee I kneel, who affrighted Mother am,
Oh from this Lyons claws keep my poor Lambe.

div.stage: Enter old Bruce, and Richmond, and above Oxford.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: The Caſtle Gates are ſhut, ſwift footed Tyranie,
That canſt when thou purſu'ſt thy wild deſires,
Out run the wantan Roe; Oh Richmond, Richmond,
I fear our ſtay all night, ha's made me witneſs
Of a day darker then night.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Yonr fears and your afflictions
Meet in one Center, for it ſeems the King
Sent Oxford in the night on the walls;
Behold where Oxford ſtands, I fear they have ſeiz'd
Your Sonne, your Wife and Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: Oxford, thou ſigne
Set up to ſhew me where my ſorrows dwell,
Martyr me not with circumſtances; but tell me,
Is it (as from thy ominous preſence there)
We may conjecture.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Becauſe you requeſt brevity,
Then by my ominous preſence here great Lords
You conjecture that you come too late.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let force our entrance,
We have tweuty men of ſpirit to dare.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: A ſcore of Cowards, Oxford,
Dar'ſt thou be honourable?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: An other time,
But now I have no leiſure, the King is here.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: In perſon.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Yes, and power;
And if the Queen and Cheſter ſpeed as the King has,
We ſhall have a pledget too for Fitzwaters loyalty,
And ſo good day, ye meet the proverb here,
Ye both are early up but near the neare.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: We ſtrongly may conclude from their intelligence
Of your Son, and fair Matilda's flight to Hartford,
Thither the Queen and Cheſter are repair'd,
Either by force or policy to obtaine her,
So that the neareſt path to our proceedings.
Is to poſt back to London, and to haſten
Her Father thither with his powers, and ſo
Secure your Sonne, his Daughter, and it may be,
Surpriſe the Queen and Cheſter.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: If we do,
If but a hair of my betrayed wife,
Or my poor boy do periſh, a head royall
Shall be ſent back, ſlight ſcratches leave no ſcars
But deep wounds are ſeeds of Civill wars.

div.head: Actus 2. Scoena 1.
div.stage: Enter King, Hubert, Lady, and Bruce.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: YOu would not then produce him.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Think of it Madam,
And for your own diſcharge, give up your Son.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I have him not to give.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: We will no more be mock'd, are all the people,
sp.stage: Enter 2 Souldiers with a Hamper, the Boy in it.
sp.l: Horſes, and Cattel voided forth the Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: All but this Hamper which ſtood underneath
The ſtairs that led into the Dungeon.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A place ſuſpicious, ſearch it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Let not rudeneſſe boaſt ſir,
She was born i'th preſence of a Prince.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Tis lock'd my Lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Where is the Key?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know not, loſt.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Cut it open.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do not, do not, indeed you'l ſpoile it then.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Well then they ſhall not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now the King is gracious.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: But fetch each man a Torch, and here before me Set it a fire.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh rather cut it ſir in a thouſand peeces;
Why did you tell me that they ſhould not cut it,
And now would burn it? who did teach you ſir
To mock a wounded heart? look, look, and they do not go
To cut it too; good ſir, I have a Jewel
Lyes conceal'd there, which I hid for feare o'th ſouldiers,
Of infinite value.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Tis open my Lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: what's in't?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.p: Marry youth in a basket ſir, here is the prety Jewel Of infinite value.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hold him faſt fellow, Hubert keepe back the mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I would be kept back, is that a Boy
To cruſh with a rude hand, alas a griſle
Look, and his very looks do not fright my Child.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Oh mother here is a man lookes very black,
(Pray do not hurt me) indeed, and if you doe,
You'l make my mother cry

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: For heavens ſakellet me kiſſe him, I warrant you the Childe was almoſt ſmotherd, come from him George.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A wo'not let me go, if I were your match,
Ide give you a good ſound box o'th eare,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Come, Come, 'we will not part you, Hubert there waits
One Brand without, ſervant to the Earle of Cheſter,
With a guard, let him Convey them both to Winſor Caſtle,
And by this ſignet to ſir Walter Blunt,
Deteyne them in his cuſtody, untill
We ſhall direct him further.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Oh brave, mother I have heard of Wiuſor Caſtle, my father
Told me there are brave bowes and arrowes; and drums there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh happy Innocent, who in ſpight of foes
Can play the pretty wanton with thy woes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: The Lord Steward ſir
Is come it ſeemes from London.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: My Lord of Wincheſter the meaning of your ſpeed?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: The Popes legate Sir,
The Cardinal Pandulp is ariv'd at London,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What newes with him; Six yeares we have ſtood
An inte • dicted man, can he bring lowder thunder?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: He brings proffers of peace ſir,
Advantagable peace too, if that you pleaſe
To make a reſignation of your Crowne:

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Good ſir ſuffer mee,
And that to him to the Popes uſe; withall;
(Paying an Annuall tribute for your Kingdomes
Of England, and of Ircland, in the preſence
Of the whole body of the Peers,) he has power
From his Holineſs to reinveſt your temples
With the rich Diadem; and with all pronounce you
Again admitted into the Church, your power
Weakned and wounded, yet may by this meanes
Lyon like, rowſe it ſelfe and remove all obſtacles
Twixt you and the high calling of a King,
Which by the reaſon you ſtood Curſt at Rome,
Receiv'd affronts ſo frequent; beſides Fitzwaters,
With Leiſter (who by the return of Bruce and Richmand
From thence to London, were upon expedition,
With there powers for Hartford Caſtle to intercept
The proceedings of the Queen and Cheſter;)
I have ſtaid upon the Legats ſpecial chardge
To attend your reſignation, potent neſſeſity
(The great diſpenſer with all Cerimony,)
Calls it a point of Policy, whereby
You build your ſelfe, ruine your enemy.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: And then you ſtand again, ſir a King abſolute
And dazel faction.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Come we will catch craft
With imitation, he that would ſcrew his ends
To his own aims, muſt mingle (when he wins)
Secret diſſemblings 'mongſt his venial ſinnes.

div.stage: Enter Souldiers, and young Bruce priſoner.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: You are mine Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Tis falſe, I am Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: This day to fortune then I ſacrifice,
As to my Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Y. Br.
sp.l: A Whore is then your Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: A Whore!

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: A raſcall Jade,
That takes with the dixterity ſhe gives; tell me
Of your Miſtreſſe and the Devil: Oh my ſtars.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: O ſir we have wayes to tame you, you remember
You brav'd me in the preſence of the King,
At Baynards Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Oh I am mad,
Yet not ſo mad, but I dare ſtill brave Cheſter,
And from the top of my affliction,
Upon thy light heel'd Mrs. wanton fortune,
Caſt from the manly temper of my blood
A noble ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You ſhall be fetter'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Fetter'd:

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yes, and ſent
Up to the King as an arch Rebel, to whom,
To whom (before) we have by Letters ſent our happy fortune.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Rebell:
By that boyling ſea of blood which thou haſt troubl'd,
Had my deſires but bodies, I would burſt
Fetters of ſteele, tear off thy canker'd fleſh,
And with thy Jaw-bone, (thou honour wounding man)
I would kill a thouſand of theſe Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Drag him
Into the Caſtle, ſince your fortunes move you,
We • 'l force you to a madneſſe.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Fool thou canſt not;
Froſt makes fire fervent, he that wiſely knows
His wealthy fate, bravely becomes his woes.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Are you ſo arm'd, away with him.

div.stage: Enter the Queene, dragging in Matilda, her hair looſe, and Face bloody.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come forward furie, witch.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Alas, why thus
Great Queen do you miſ-uſe me? credite me
I do not feare to die, young Infants do it;
Nor wiſh I life, the murtherer enjoyes it;
But let me know my treſpaſſe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I'me made your ſtale,
The King, the King your ſtrumpet; oh thou wretch,
The matter my ſpleen!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear me but ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, I will thee ſpeak,
That every ſyllable may ſerve inſtead
Of a fierce wind to blow my fiercer fury
Into the faſhion of a puniſhmen,
Fitting the daring of thy treſpaſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Heare me;
By theſe red marks, regiſters of your raſhneſſe,
And by theſe tears, the fruits of my affliction,
That the King paſſionately purſues my love,
Is truth uncontr • dicted; but if I
Did ever think you wrong, let mine honour be
buried in dark oblivion.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sin's a ſweet tame Serpent, they muſt beguile
Cloath rude errors, in a ſoft ſmooth ſtile:
• ut ſtr • mpſt thou ſhalt ruin't.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Shift for your ſelfe Madam,
Richmond eſcap'd from London with the powers
Leavied by Leiſter, and Fitzwater, (who
Were ſtai'd by Winchester, and the Legate Pandulph)
Hath reſcued Bruce, got again the Caſtle,
sp.stage: Ent. Y. Bruce, and Richmond with Souldiers.
sp.l: And make you now their ſearch.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Ceaſe on the Queen;
Madam you are our priſoner,

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Keep Cheſter ſafe good Ricmond;
Ha! oh what rude hand
Hath ras'd this Book of beauty? a face where vertue
Intelligibly ſtood to charm the Reader: Tell me Cozen,
And by the thouſands of thy tears, and fears
No tittle, place, degree, the very Grave
Shall not ſecure the offender.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: There is death in's angry eyes.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.l: The rude Souldiers
My noble Cozen hail'd me thus, and tore me,
And would have ſure done worſe, but that the Queen,
The wondrou • kind Queen in her royall perſon,
Came with a troop of well appointed Souldiers,
and reſcued me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: She mocks me ſure.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: The Queen ſo kind.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O Couſin had you ſeen
How good ſhe was in her quick ſpeed, how zealous
To relieve innocence, you would have thought
She'd kil'd them with her frowns e're ſhe came at them,
So lamentably miſerable were my ſufferings,
So excellently noble was her charity.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Now by my life, 'twas honour in the higheſt,
Becauſe a foe, and gracious Madam, not
To be out bid in this brave Mart of honour,
You ſhall have a ſafe Convoy, and of quality
Fitting your perſon, to convey (with your freedome)
To th'angry King our loves, that he may ſee
How plain to him we mean, and how nobly
Unto a goodneſſe of ſo fair deſervings
As this now ſhowne; ſee there be preſent order
For her Majeſties attendance, and ſwee Coz
With-draw from the cold ayr.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Farewell Matilda;
Oh pardon me for heavens ſake, now I find
Thy ſoul is Chriſtall.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Remember to the King
Good Madam my great ſorrows; and forget not
To tell him this, that woman in whoſe heart
Vertue and honour ſtand a paire of Centinels;
The Sea may ſooner flame, fire admit froſt,
E're ſuch a woman fall from heaven: Oh ſhe,
Who as a regular ſtar, keeps vertues ſpeare,
Shews like a Pearl hung in an Angel • eare.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou noble ſoul of goodneſſe.

div.stage: A Chaire of ſtate diſcover'd Tables and Chaires reſponcible, a Guard making a lane: Enter between the • , King John, Pandulph the Popes Legate, Cheſter Oxford, and all the Kings Party: After them, Fitzwater, Richmond, Leiſter, and Bruce; the King (holding the Crown) kneeling on the left ſide of the Chaire, Pandulph poſſeſſing it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Lo in the ſight of Prelates Peers,
Of Earth and Heaven, of all that heares
My words; I John Plantagaent,
(VVith all ſubmiſſive reverence,) ſet
My Crowne at the moſt ſacred foot
Of Innocent the Third, unto't
I joyne my Kingdom • , giue them free
Unto his pious clemencie:
And for the follies of my Raigne,
Heats of my youth, and the rough ſtraine
Of riper years, my Rebellions, my high hand,
My ſix yeares Interdictien, and
A • l my miſ-doings; I this, and thoſe,
Submit to the Popes power to diſcloſe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You have by times recracted, and your foot now
Beats out a certain path; in theſe Lords ſights of I do
Produce the Letter, drawn Obligatory
From John of England to his Holineſſe,
Peruſe it ſir, you are there oblig'd to pay,
(As yearly from this day Renting your Kingdoms)
To Innocent the Third, and to his Succeſſors
A thouſand marks per annum.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: It runnes ſo.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes, three hundred for Ireland, & ſeven for England.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Do not peruſe it John, though thou and we
Have had ſome bickerings, yet let me counſell thee,
This is my Countries Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You, and your Country
Have cauſe in this Cauſe to rejoyce.

sp.speaker: Eitz.
sp.l: Good, good, Sir Pandvlph,
Though in our filiall love to our Mother Church,
By his Holineſſe command, we ſtay'd from Hartford,
Yet lets have fair play, do not wrong that mother,
Apparelling her comely holy face,
With a forehead full of frowns, pleited proceedings.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You raile.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I do not raile,
Although I hold and reverence the Chair,
(We had been at Hartford elſe, and not at London,)
Yet in a true breaſt we ſhould nothing ſee,
But holy pure, unmixt ſimplicy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Give me the pen.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Will you then ſigne?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yes, you rough Sonnes of faction,
And hook your ſtubborn noſtrils, this is Rubarb
To your ſmooth pallats: give me the pen to write.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Do not write John.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Do not prate fool.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: In ſooth that write
Will wrong thee; Children and Fools tell truth,
Remember that.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: There was no way like this,
To beat a path out to your peace.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Right Reverend
And holy Sir, receive to the Popes uſe,
His will, and your own charge: Sir, deſcend not,
But ere you re-inveſt me, hear me tell
A tale of ſorrow, behold here theſe Lords,
Who had been now bruiſing the face of peace
With unkind buffets, but for VVincheſter,
Your ſtrict compulſion, and their ſeeming fear
Of deſerv'd interdiction; but oh ſpright,
No Devill deceives like th'houſhold hypocrite,
Theſe of my Court, with young Brace now inſconc'd
At Hartford, whither it may hair brain'd Richmond
hath retir'd his diſcontents.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: We miſſe our hopes elſe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Theſe bandy faction with me, and with their drum •
(Lew'd linguiſts to interpret their diſloyalties)
Brave me i'th field, deform th' afflicted face
Of trembling England with foul bloody ſtain • ,
Larums at hideous midnight, they break my ſleeps,
Fill them with fearfull dreams, terrible ſtartings,
And with the griefe of my unfriendly fears,
Force me to pierce my pillow with my tears.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Unnaturall cruellty,
Able to melt marble into compaſſionate tears.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Dainty diſſembler.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: Now may it pleaſe you—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Peace untill his holineſſe command be ſiniſhed;
Aſcend your now true Seat ſir, and from the hand
Of my ſelfe Pandulph, Legate for the Pope,
Obſerving the due payments ſpecified,)
Receive your Crown and Kingdoms; and with them
We here pronounce your abſolute readmiſſion
Into the Church, and from his holneſſe
We re-inveſt you, with all Powers, Prerogatives,
Freedomes, Communities, (and in the ſtrength of effecacy,)
That conſtantly adhears to lawfull Princes,
And an obedient Son unto the Church,
Long life to John of England, VVales and Ireland,
The lawfull King!

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: I am mad.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: So, ſo, now we muſt ſuffer
The Kingdoms ancient Liberties, Land, lives,
And all to run the courſe that he ſhall ſteere,
Good heaven that I were dead, what do I here.

sp.speaker: O Bru.
sp.l: But i'le not aſſe-like bear my Countries wrongs,
Mine own at home, and like a Court Camelion,
Give thanks unto mine injurer: hear me King John.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You ſhall hear us ſir firſt; we have been clouded
Six years, but like the Sun in his Meridian,
We now again are glorious; thus in briefe,
Leiſter we require ſtrong pledge for your loyalty;
Bruce call your mad Son home from Hartford,
Your Wife and Sonne ſhall better ſpeed at Guilford,
For Richmond in our re-aſſumed power.
We will proclaime him Traytor, and Fitzwater,
Either give up Matilda for your faith, or heare
What we ſhall ſentence.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: We muſt ſtand then
What thunder you ſhall throw, perform with us,
We kiſſe your royall hands.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: If not, we ſtand
Rocks in our reſoluton.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: D'ee heare them now ſir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Nay, nay, let him hear me too then:
Lord Legate Pandulph; thus 'tis,
And thus you may informe his holineſſe,
In a field cal'd running-Mead' twixt Staines and VVinſor,
After ſome bloody noſes on both ſides,
I tell truth I; there the King and Barrons
Met for diſcuſſion of conceiv'd wrongs,
And indeed not miſconceiv'd, our Houſes, Honours,
Our Fathers freedomes, the Lands ancient Liberties
(Unjuſtly to encreaſe ſome private Cofers)
Felt daily Demunition, there to Covenants drawn,
(Bearing the name and ſence of Magna Charta,
Which many hundred years may be ſeen hereafter)
King John ſubſcrib'd, we ſwore him fealty.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Which fealty they deny'd, till our aſſoylment
Of our ſix years Interdiction, forcing us therefore
To ſeal unlawfull liberties.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Upon our honours,
They were but what Antiquity prov'd lawful.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Oh but my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Tut, tut, Lord me no Lords,
He broak, we powted, I tell plain truth I,
Yet fell into no relapſe of hoſtility,
But wot ye what, he caſts a covetous eye,
Upon my Daughter, paſſionately purſues her,
There had been other pledges but our oathes elſe,
(For heaven knows thtm he had) and (amongſt the reſt)
Matilda muſt be my pledge, for well he deem'd
They yielding their • , ſhame would brand my denyall,
But catch craft, when we put truth to triall,
Kings ſhould have ſhining ſouls, and white deſires
Enflam'd with zeale, not parch'd by Paphian fires;
So ſhines the ſoul in which vertue doth ſhrowd,
Is a ſerene skie beſpotted with no cloud,
But a Copper conſcience whil'ſt the head wears Gold,
Is but a plain down-right untruth well told,
Come, come, I cannot fawn.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But in the paſſion
Gf a Dog ſir you can ſnarl; have you talk all your words?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I have told truth I.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Then we will fall to deeds,
Oxford command a Guard, and preſently
Take them to'th Tower; we can now talk and do,
Away with them, and muzzel thoſe fierce Maſtiffes,
That durſt leap at the face of Majeſtie,
And ſtrike their killing fangs into honours heart;
Are they not gone? we ſhall be paſſionate
In your delay.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: Come Leiſter, let us wear
Our ſufferings like Garland.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Tempeſt nor death,
Could never ou • do Leiſter, who dares dye
Laughing at times poyſon'd integrity.

sp.speaker: Fitz
sp.l: Now by my troth 'twas very nobly ſpoken,
Shall I turne tale; no, no, no, lets go,
But how things will be carried; ha! are theſe teares
Body of me? they are; Shall I go like a ſheep
With this pair of Lyons; ha, ha, ha,
I do laugh now John, and i'le tell thee why,
Th'art yet in thy green May, twenty ſeven ſummers
Set in our Kalends, but when forty Winters more
Shall roun'd thy forehead with a field of ſnow,
And when thy comely veins ſhall ceaſe to flow,
When thoſe majeſtick eyes ſhall float in rhumes,
When giant Nature her own ſelfe conſumes,
When thy ſwift Pulſes ſhall but ſlowly pant,
When thou art all a Volum of my want,
(That like a tale-ſp • nt fire thou ſhalt ſ • nck,)
Then John upon this leſſon thou wilt think •
He dyes a happy old man, whoſe ſweet youth
Was a continued ſacrifice to truth;
I muſt weep now indeed.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Away with them.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Unto King John, the favour of his holineſſe,
With peace and happineſſe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Which we return
With all filiall obedience—look up Oxford,
The day breaks, and the Sun hath chaſte the night
Out of our Hemiſpheare.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Your news ſir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Letters from the Queen ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Was the Earl Richmond there with any powers
E're your departure.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: No may it pleaſe your Majeſtie, we heard not of him,
But all on your part went fair and fortunate

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh Oxford now they have her, flie back like lightning,
Tell him this day wee'l meet them all at Barnet.

sp.speaker: Ox
sp.l: But her Father and her friends impriſonment
May obdurate her hea • t, they dare not ſure
On the great perill of a curſe to fall
Into a Relapſe now you are abſolute.
Faith 〈◊〉 trie ſmooth paths to your ends, to releaſe them,
I hold the winningſt way to captivate
Their duties, and Matilda to your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Good, do not kill me • oy before our going
Inſtantly thou ſhalt flie with the Lords releaſe,
We pine in our delayes, oh Cupid ſwiftly
Fly into Paphoes, and from thy Mothers ſhrine,
Catch but a nimble wanton flame, and caſt it
Into the buſie Kingdome of my heart,
That it may teach my tongue the art of victory,
And every year unto thy well-ſpent Quiver
I'le add a ſhaft, and call it Cupids love Dart;
Come Oxford, I tread methinks on aire,
Untill I read that Volum of ſweet grace,
The well writ ſtory of Matild • 's face.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: She yeelds at laſt my life on't ſir.

div.head: Actus 3. Scoena 1.
div.stage: En • er Brand reading of a Letter.

sp.p: WIll Brand, theſe are to certifie, That Fortune, Miſtreſſes of Changes, with my unluckie ſtars, hathrendred m • a priſoner to my moſt mortall Enemy young Bruce.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: My entreaty is none of the nobleſt, but direct againſt my blood, my deſires, and my deſervings.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Oh that I had a leg of that young Bruce, but minc'd and butter'd.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I am credibly poſſeſt, his Majeſtie hath into your cuſtody comm • ited his Mother, and her young Sonne George, whereby you have occaſion caſt into your hand to parallel their; ſufferings with my fortunes, not that I would have you baniſh humanity.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: He need never have writ that Bawds and Serjeants have ſav'd me the labour.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Nor give to deep a wound to Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Another labour ſav'd too,
Uſurers do it daily

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: But as I let you underſtand how I am here accommodated, ſo ſhape the duty of a Servant to parallel in their perſons, your villified Mr Ralph Cheſter.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p:
Brave Lord, the Laddar of my fortunes, 〈◊〉
ſuffer on that ſide, and for humanities ſake, and thred-b ••
conſcience (a couple of couſin-Germans, that thrice a weeke know not where to get a ſupper;) ſhall the friends of him that ſtands Lord of thy fortunes, and thy profeſt foe, fare well here; now I talk of fare, I receiv'd this Letter yeſterday, and ſince they have uei • h • r eaten bit, nor drunk drop, nor by theſe ten ſtealers ſhall not, till I heare againe from my Lord—: Come o • lt madam Mother, and your youg prating brat—they do look hungry already.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What would our unkind Jaylor?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sure Mother Mr. Brand hath brought us v • ctuals.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No ſirrah, I come to tell you to day i • faſting day.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Two dayes together,
Good Mr. Brand, 'tis not mine own want beggs,
But my poor Boyes; I have held him pretty paſtime,
To have him yet forget that wild woolf hunger,
And ſtill the harmleſſe ſoul would point each period
Of his ſport, erying Mother give me bread.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: She has a winning way,
Her carriage and her perſon are both exquiſite:
Fai •• tell me Madam, what would you give for ſome victuals
To give your Son?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Any thing, ſet thou the price thou ſhalt have Gold.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And truly ſir, if you'l but give me a Cake,
Or a Capons legge, when I am a man,
I'le give you twenty ſhillings to buy your Boy fine things.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: If you dare lye with me,
You and your Sonne ſhall both have ſuſtenance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hearken good heaven, what ſaies the man?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: He would Ile with you Mother,
But then when I am a bed too, there
Will be no room for my, Father.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Be as plain and briefe as I was, dare yee do' • ?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No thou bad man, I dare no • .

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No body ſhall ſee • by this hand,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt thou feind, ſhouldſt thou 〈◊〉 Ca •• e do' • ,
The Towers would tremble, and turn Intelligencers
To all the paſſengers; the walls would ſhudder,
The E • cutchions, Streamers, Baune • s, all the Reliques
Of fame and honour, would fall down, to ſee
Honour and Fame ſo wounded.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: See! I am aſham'd to hear you,
If ſuch ſinnes could not be done without being ſeen,
Informers would have a fine trade on't, a Parators place
Would counvaile five Serjeants; ha, ha, ſeen kither;
Why there would not be ſheets en ugh in the Land
For the penitent, and innocent Beadles enough to correct the
Guilty; Come, come, we'l do't i' • h dark then,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: In he dark ſaid'ſt thou?
Oh in the deepeſt darkneſſe, the white Angels
Will ſtare upon thee, and with flaming eyes.
Will make make the room appear to thy wild conſcience,
Twice lighter then the Sunne:
'Tis a foul Devil that inſinuates to thee,
He has borrowed a white robe, pluck it off from him,
And thou wilt ſee him a black hideous monſter,
How with a ſlaviſh look he will creep from thee,
Diſpleas'd that thou art falne again in love,
With holy goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How my Conſcience wambles.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Do, do, good ſir, think of it,
It will make you give's ſome bread.
And then you'l be a very honeſt man,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I have heard you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And with a thirſty ſoul I hope.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Yes, as Uſurers heare Sermons, more for novelty then integrity, I love good words when I pay nothing for 〈◊〉 ; what do you ſee in me that I ſhould appear unworthy of your grant •

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Becauſe in that requeſt,
Thou appear'ſt to me as ugly as a Toad.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A Toad •

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I, and a Frog to if you go to that,
Doe not cry Mother.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Get you both in, by this victorious ſword,
And by the horrid odious compariſon,
(for ſuch a one firſt • u e made compariſons odious)
Ye get not a bit this ſeven dayes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: By that time
My Boy and I ſhall make a pair of happy ones
In youder glorious Kingdom; tell me George,
Shall this bad man abnſe thy Fathers bed?
Or ſhall we faſt yet longer?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The boy will conſent I warrant you,
The Pages have inſtructed him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Indeed I am very hungry:

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Did I not tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: But rather then this Goat ſhall lie in my fathers place,
Indeed • 'le faſt this ſeven years.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ah noble boy,
Sweet plant of goodneſſe, thou haſt prov'd it true,
Vertue will wiſh the good it cannot do.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Aterribly ugly Toad.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Good ſir ye muſt be patient.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Patient,
Bitterneſſe dwels with me: if I do not put him
To an eternall patience, that ſhall dare
To witch me into that dull fit of fools;
Matilda won and loſt •

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Good ſir

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Away;
Struggle not with the tempeſt of my blood,
That will undo th • e.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Richmond Lyon like,
(After we ſent our Letter with the Foree •
The Barrous had prepar'd,) clouded our day,
And made our fortunes his.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: They • out o'th Tower to,
Fitzwater Bruce, and Leiſter, with freſh powers,
Are not a league hence.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The Lyon Richmond, a Hare had he met with any
But field Mice, Rats, Run-awayes, and Weezles,
Frighted even with the waving of a Flag,
They would have call'd • ſcar-crow ſtufi'd with ſtraw,
And bound upon a ten groats Iriſh Garron,
Oh there is nothing certaine but our ſorrows,
Our borrow'd bliſſe is but the ſhuttl • -cock
Of a dayes paſtime.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have paſtim'd her, if tearing be a paſtime,
Let that comfort you,
I have torne her almoſt to d: ath.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Matilda.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And would you have it comfort me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I know it does, call but up your Troops
Brayely again, recover her, and read
Upon her face my fury.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh ye cruell one,
Crueller then the flame that turn'd to Clnders
The fair Epheſian Temple; wilde as a Woolf,
The Bear is not ſo bloody, teare her hairs,
Which when they took their • aſtime with the winds,
Would charm the aſtoniſh'd gazer; tear that face,
Lovely as is the morning in whoſe eyes
Stands writ the hiſtory of her heart, intioing
The raviſh'd Reader to runne on, 'pon whoſe eye lids
Diſcretion dwels, which when a wilde thought
Would at thoſe Caſements like a Theefe ſteale in,
Playes her heart's noble friend, and ſhuts out ſin.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O why then ſir, if ſhe be ſuch a volum
Of white unvanquiſh'd 〈◊〉 would you ſtain.
And blot the ſair leaves with your 〈◊〉 deſir •
Ghaſte, froſtie boſomes, brook no luſt-born fires.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: She has put me to my ſophiſtry.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I knew I was made
Your ſtaie for her obtaining.
Oh why
Raiſe you ſo high a Piramis to her praiſe,
And proſtrate your own vertue? if ſhe be
Such a Book of goodneſſe (with bad deſires)
Why do you read her? He no truth intends,
Seeks to corrupt that Text which he commends,
Good ſir conſider it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Well, I will think on' • , and you will have done.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Now is the time my Lord,
If e're you would be fortunate in your deſires,
Richmond, young Bruce, Matilda,
(With the Earl of Cheſter priſoner,) • and a ſlight convoy
But of ſome threeſcore Horſe, and two hundred Archer •
Are now i'th valley croſſing of the County,
'Tis thought for Eſſex.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Where are their main Forces?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Inſcon'ſt in Hartford Caſtle, our Forces yet
Not ſo diminiſh'd, or in rout for want
Of their loſt Generall, but if you pleaſe,
We dare with hope aſſail them.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I will be Generall,
Order the Powers you have for preſent on-ſet.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My Lord, you ſaid you would conſider.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I am conſidering bravely how to charge
The Foe juſt in the face: Matilda I am now thy Souldier,
Friend of my heart, the King himſelfe comes for thee,
Who ſhall in this dayes doings amply prove,
Honour takes fire from the flame of love.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Good fortune on our ſide ſir.

div.stage: Exeunt. Manet Queen. A Charge afar off.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hear not that prayer
Good heaven, oh tempt not vertue to adorn
A foul Cauſe with fair fortunes: Hark, hark, they meet,
And now pell mell the angry Lords do liſt
Unnaturall ſwords, good heaven keep ſafe the King,
But let his Cauſe miſcarry; I w ll not ſtay
To ſee him ſo purſue thoſe wild deſires,
Which cannot ſure end well; i'le to the Lords
So near at hand, and with Matilda's Father,
Accommodate my griefs, and let there be
Her feares, my tears, the Kings infirmity.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oxford, ſh • 's now the Kings.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Moſt miſerable Maid.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Moſt excellent Matilda all are thy friends,
Imperious love fat on my l • ance juſt then,
When on the pan • ing breſt of daring Richmond.
(Who like a me • ancholly ſullen Cloud,
Eclips'd thy Chariot) thou didſt ſee me print
My re •• leſſe paſſion: Oxford keep my happineſſe,
Juſt with that care thou wouldſt oreſerve that pair
Of pr • c ous things, thine eye; Cheſters ingag'd
Deep in the Cha • e, and we muſt te • ch him off;
Pardon me honour that I plac • d love firſt,
My doings now are thine.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Keep near the King, Gentlemen,
His unbounded ſpirit may looſe him el • e; good Madam
Do not lament ſo, though your friends are • catter'd,
Y'are in a ſpheare of happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh that great power,
That many times out of this toy I hath taken me,
Deliver me again, becauſe again,
Vertue hath made me miſerabl.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Oh that neceſſity
Should force us unto flight, baſe flight, repugnant
To man and honour. Ha! nappy flight now,
That brought me this way.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Cozen.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Oxford, either give back
That pure unſpotted Dove, from the killing Tallon
Of the forgetfull King, or thou or I
Muſt never ſee him more. •

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: That to our fortunes,
I muſt not faile the King ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: I muſt not faile then
To get her as I can ſir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: We are ſcatter'd now
Paſte making head againe.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: But I have made ſhift to get my Cuz agen ſir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let us not ſtay now to expoſtulate, Neceſſity
Directs us to our friends not a league diſtant,
If we not fly we are loſt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good Cuz lets flie,
Tis no difgrace to obey neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Oh I could ſtamp and tear that hagge neceſſity,
Bitter neceſſity, thou ſcourge of things
That forces Lyons to wear Swallows wings.

div.stage: Exe. Manet Ox. to him enter King, Cheſter, & others.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: You have plaid the Souldier ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The Souldier Cheſter; I am ſo light with joy,
I could do any thing.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Troth ſir would it might pleaſe you then to grace
Me with the Preſident-ſhip of Picardy,
Falne in this laſt Rebellion from the Lord
Bruce un • o your Crown.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Tis thine as certaine
As Matilda is the Kings: Oh Chester, now Matilda
Is in the Kings power.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: No ſir, ſhe is in heavens.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Who's this, Oxford, lets help to raiſe him up.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What ſaiſt thou man? Matilda, where is Matilda?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Young Bruce in his flight happening upon this way
For her recovery gave me fierce aſſault;
I did ſtand for you ſir as much as man could,
Till my miſ-fortune found me, then I fell;
To him eame Richmond, and with all ſpeed poſſible
They have carried her to'th Lords on tother ſide the h • ath.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh villaine, villaine •
Suppoſe he had cut thy hear • ſtrings, hadſt thou caſt •
Thy dying eye upon Matilda's face?
She would have ſhot another ſpirit into thee,
More daring then the firſt, at leaſt more fortunate.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Let him be convey'd to'ch Town and dreſt,
Our beſt courſe is now to with-draw, the Lords
Are ſtrong, and may give us dangerous chaſe elſe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What are our hopes
Like Garlands, • pon afflictions forehead worn,
Kiſt in the morning, and at evening torne.

div.stage: Exit. A Table and Chaires ſet out.
Enter Fitzwater, Old Bruce, young Bruce, Richmond, and Leiſter.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: The day is then the Kings.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: White victory
Clapt on her ſilver wings, with a ſullen face,
Took leave of us, and pitched upon his Tent,
Where ſhe ſat ſmiling, while neceſſity.
Enforced our flight.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Oh that witch Neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, well, away with the witch,
Tis well you brought Matilda off; come, come,
Aud brther Bruce you have a Wife and Sonne
Unjuſtly detayn'd from you, I am injur'd,
I pray ſet you our feet into the path
Of our proceedings.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Lets with our powers
Raze Winſor walls.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Now you are i'th field ſtraight,
Give old men leave; you would raze! what would you raze •
Your reputation with your raſh proceedings;
Come, come, hear your Father.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Why let him ſpeak them,

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: Firſt let us take up our affronts in order,
And fix by ours, the Generalls grievances,
The crying groans of England, whoſe blubberd cheeks
Are ſtiffe with tears, to ſee their privildedges
Daily impair'd.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Let's ſend to the French King,
Proffer him our aſſiſtance, to trans-fer
The Crown from John to him, if at ſuch a day
He will put over a ſtrong Navie Royall,
With an Army for the attempt, with which (our Forces
Making one body) both at at Sea and Land,
We bid fair for our freedoms.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I do not like it.

sp.speaker: Y. Eru.
sp.l: S'foot, you will like nothing;
Let us be ring'd and nooz'd,

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: Beſides, being aſſoil'd of his ſix years Interdiction,
Thoſe that before fled from him as a Leaper,
Will now flock to him.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: They begin already,
(Although we ſeek (with our own) their good,) to cenſure
And call hoſtility plain faction.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: This is my reſolve, I ſay there is no way
To fix our freedomes, but to call in Philip
And make him King.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: So think we all.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I but I think not ſo,
Though y'are all wiſe for Philip, he'l be a gainer,
But what will you get by't? They run on Rocks and ſhelves,
Can can counſell others, not ſecure themſelves.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: We muſt and will do ſomething.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: You will ſend to Philip,
Inſtruct him to proceed, it may be furniſh
His Navie with our Pilots, he lands, we proffer
Change, John for Philip; oh can you think,
That we can undergo a heavier ſtroke
From a Naturall, then from a Forreigne yoak;
Go to, go to, who in no eſtate can reſt,
They may change oft, but ſeldome comes the beſt.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: I am diverted.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Which way would you ſteer then?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: By the ſame Compaſſe, but not upon this parallel,
I do not like the line; but this wee'l do,
Wee'l ſend for Lewis, Philips Sonne the Dolphine,
And to him (ſeemingly) preter the proffer,
A Crown will fire him; may be he ſhall land,
But with no more Force then we pleaſe; and it may be
He ſhall take a fiſher Town, for every Nation
Can take away their trading as the time goes,
Our m • ine Force being ready, we will hover
'Twixt John and Lewis; if John deny an oath
To redreſſe our griefes, and become regular
And Hoſtage for the keeping it, we joyne
With the French and fright him further; If he conſent,
We fall on his part then, expulſe Lewis,
And ſend him to the Seas again; the Dolphine
Is young and may be wrought on, but old Philip
Is dangerouſly politick, with foot aſhore,
Hee'l brook no jugling, both eaſe, and ſafety
We work on Willowes, but when we ſtrike at Oaks,
We ſweat, and ſometimes hurt with our own ſtrokes.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: It ſhall be thus effected.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: But let report divulge his Landing,
With more eminent danger then we will let him practiſe.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: For this time
Riſe then; See the Queen and Ladies,
Good Madam caſt off ſadneſſe,
Matilda we are all here i'th City ſafe;
The very hearts o'th Citizens (men injur'd
In their priviledges as we are) they are ours,
What ſhould we fear then?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You are all ſuch friends,
I am poor in my well-meaning thankfuln̄eſſe.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: A Barge with divers youthfull Citizens,
Apparell'd rich like Masquers, is now land'd
Upon the Stairs, hearing the Queen was here,
• ithall this meeting of their noble friends,
Proffer their loves and duties to conclude
And grace the evening with their Revels.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: In the Hall wee'l meet them. Did not I tell you
Theſe Citizens were noble lads our friends?
Waite on the Ladies Lords, I am here your Graces ſervant,
By my troth I thank'em, they will crown our feaſt,
And credite me, having ſuch a princely gueſt.

div.stage: Enter at one doore Fitzwater, old Bruce, young Bruce, Leiſter, Matilda and Ladies; at the other doore, the King, Cheſter, Oxford, Maſquers.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Now by my troth they are gallants,
Citizens ſaid you; now I remember to,
Ye do go gallant in your Shops, no wonder then,
If in Maſques you cut it. I remember Gentlemen,
Your Fathers wore a king of comely habite,
Comely, becauſe it wel became the reverend name of Citizens,
But now let a Knight walk with you in your ſhops,
(And I commend you for't, ye keep the faſhion)
We know not which is which—; how my tongue ranges,
And night grows old, mad times, muſt have mad changes;
Come, come, a Hall, a hall.

div.stage: The Maſquers take the Ladies, and fall to the Dance.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Beleeve me you have done well.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Pox a' theſe Cats guts, how they ſqueak.
Methinks a rattling ſheep-skin luſtily boxt,
Would thunder brave amongſt them.

div.stage: One of the Torch bearers takes Matilda.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I can dance no more indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I am deceiv'd if that fellow did not carry
A Torch e'n now;
Will you ſhame the Gentleman?
Dance when I bid you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh me, that graſpe was like the Kings.

sp.speaker: O. Bru.
sp.l: Dance Cuz.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: In good deed dance,
Or you will make me angry.
Body of me, that's too much for a Torch-bearer,
You ſir Jack, ſir Jack, ſhe is no whit-leather,
She will not ſtretch I aſſure you, if you come hither
For love ſo 'tis.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: For love.

sp.speaker: Eitz.
sp.l: But if you and your Company,
Put on forgetfull rudeneſſe, pray take your Cupid yonder,
Your thing of feathers, and your Barge ſtands ready
To bear ye all aboard the ſhip of Fools,
I am plain Robin—paſſion of me!
Look if he do not threaten me; I will ſee thee,
Wert thou King John himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: The King!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh which way ſhall I flie?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I would not leave ſo ſweet a chaſte companion.

div.stage: Exeunt Qu. Mat. Rich, and Ladies. In the buſsle, Fitzwater drops one of his Gloves, Hubert takes it up, and goes after the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What's this, one of her Fathers Gloves?
This ſhall be drawn upon the luckie hand of a thriving plot.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Behold thy King, thine Bruce, one of the Fathers
Of theſe retir'd factions; Richmond, the King,
And thine • ough Leiſter; is this ſtill your neſt
Wherein to hatch another Scorpions Egge,
To ſting the afflicted boſome of your Country,
To bruiſe her ſides with the earth-wounding hoofes
Of War-apparell'd Horſes, whoſe dreadful neighings
May fright her pale face to a bloody bluſh,
And again make her groane.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Your pardon ſir,
By my good Sword I knew ye not.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: No, if you had,
Your dangerous Brother Bruce and you, had laid
Some plot for his ſacred perſon; then pleaded ignorance,
That ye took him as he ſeem'd, a ſawcy ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Cheſter, Thou art not noble in thy c • nſure,
And ſawn 'ſt thy ſelfe into the abus'd favour
Of the to-credulous King.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Oh temptation, what a Devill art thou;
Now by my blood young man, you court my ſpleen
In a vain glorious ſhape; Cheſter fawne,
Juſt heaven forbid it.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: An Axe upon your neck, che juſt heavens give you •
And that in heaven were juſtice—

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: Sonne, y'are too full of choller.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Choller, Halter.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: By the maſſe that's neer the choller.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Upon your lives no more, the King is here;
Fitzwater, I did not come to quarrell with thee,
I would have ſuch a good man ever neer me,
And for a floriſh to the reſt (of whom
As of old Bruce we have) we will require ſtrict pledges, and
Fitzwater let thy Daughter live at Court, ſhe ſhall be kept.
I'th cuſtody of the Queen, but as no pledge.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: The Queen is gracioue.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Come, to their ruines leave theſe turbulent Lords.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: But ſuppoſe the Queen ſhould ride abroad to hunt,
And leave Matilda ſolitary at home,
I think the King would come and comfort her.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I am of thy mind, I think he would.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Would he ſo?— I would have no one hear.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: They cannot man.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Pray tell the King, ile keep my Girle at home,
And comfort her my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You will.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: John, John, now I ſpeak out;
You made your Maſque for this, a Maſque indeed,
And we-aday! that it ſhould prove a Cover
For ſuch a night of Tempeſts, ſuch wilde affections,
Such an ill-favour'd night.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hubert, is't done?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Paſt expectation, I have better'd your plot,
And got the Queene too,
And will bring them early in the morning to'th Court.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Have the Torch-bearers given fire to the plot?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: They mixt with oppertunity.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I do not like this whiſpering,
Where are the Ladies and Matilda?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The Ladies are at the further ſide the Caſtle,
But by a Glove you ſent by a Gentleman,
That ſaid he ſerv'd Earle Leiſter, that with him
She and the Queene ſhould flie for ſafety whither
You had directed him, glad of any ſcare,
They took a Barge, another leapt in after them,
But whom he was I know not.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: Sent you a Glove.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: A Glove indeed I miſſe, but I ſent none.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: This is a Riddle.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I will play Oedipus, and expound it for you,
As Hubert has infus'd; you drop'd your Glove,
Ingenius Hubert found it, and (though we
Had directed otherwiſe,) he employ'd a Gentleman
Of our own Chamber, one unknown to Matilda,
To bring it as your cloſe intellige ce
For her flight with him; he that leapt into 'th Barge,
As they put of, was Oxford, now we have her
Never again to loſe her.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: By my vext blood
King John, this is not honourable.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: We are betray'd,
All that bore Torches in the Maſque to night,
Were of the Guard, who upon a receiv'd watch-word,
Fell to their Arms, beat down all oppos'd them,
And are ſhaping their courſe this way.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Lets meet'em,
We have an injur'd patience, came death in whirle-winds,
Ile be the firſt ſhall front him; to thy prayers John,
Pray heartily, that thy friends fatall points
May pierce theſe hearts; for if they miſſe 'tſhall prove
The bloodi ſt beauty ſtory ever told
To fright the Readers ſouls; a purple cloud
Shall ſhaddow England, the whole Land ſhall • ele,
The Center gr • a • s, thy very Crown ſhall ſtand
Trembling upon thy Temples, till it fall
A Mourner at thy fames black funerall.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Oh noble Nephew.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, let 'em rave on; Ingenious Hubert •
That couldſt ſo ſwifty apprehend a ſmooth
Path to'th poſſeſſion of Matilda!
Quit Oxford from her charge; unto thy care
The King commends the Miſtreſſe of his heart,
I'th morning let me ſee her.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: She ſhall waite upon you ſir.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: The Barrons threaten high ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let them burſt.
Come Gentlemen, to'th Barge, and ſo to'th Court,
To clip our wiſhes, perills appear ſport.

div.head: Actus 4. Scoena 1.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I Wonder how my pair of Priſoners fadge?
I am ſomething dogged too a to'ther ſide,
That thus long have not ſeen them, nor have they eate •
I am ſure ſince they came in; in yon Madams eye
I am as ugly as a Toad, I will ſee her,
And contemn her—, you and your brat come out,
Heres meat, I am ſure you are hungry.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: O Mother, will you be ſick now?
Mr. Boand hath brought us meat.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh on my knee ſir
I thank you, not for my want, for I feel
Nature almoſt quite vanquiſh'd; but for my Sonne;
He may live long to thank you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Give but my Mother
A little piece of bread, and if I live,
(as yet I may do, if you can be mercifull)
I will tell my Father ſuch good things of you,
He ſhall return your kindneſſe treble back
To your honeſt boſome; Oh Mother for ſome bread.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Some bread?
Why to have an honeſt boſome (as the world goes)
Is the next way to want bread; i • faith tell me,
How have you paſt the time you wanted Victu •• l • ?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Very hardly,
And ſtill the poor Boy ſighin • , would ſay, Mother
You look very hungry, I did think ſtraight how ha • d
Your heart was, then we both did fall a weeping,
Cling'd our lean armes about each others neck,
And ſat a pair of mou • ers.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Delicate paſtime, Toads love no other;
Look yee, here is bread.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Oh if you be a good man, give me but a bit
To give my Mother, poor ſoul look how ſhe looks!
Indeed ſhe's very hungry.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Yes, ſo is my Dogge,
I muſt keep this for his breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Give but my boy one bi • ,
And the Saints ſure will look how good you are,
They will be glad to ſee you charitable,
And call it excellent compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No, cunning from a Toad 'twill p • yſon him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: It will not ſir, indeed I am ſo hungry,
I could eat Rats or Mice.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Your to'ther hair braine,
Your wilde mad Sonne, retaines my Lord a Priſoner,
Uſes him baſely, and you muſt ſuffer for't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Give me but Paper, Pen and Inck, i'le wrile,
And charge him to fall down, and li • k the duſt.
Thy Lord ſhall ſet his foot on, I will conjure him:
And woe away his wildneſſe by the groars
I ſu • fer'd for him, I'le threaten his denyall
With a Mothers family-conſounding curſe:
This I will do, or any thing that may
But purchaſe my poor Boy one bit of bread.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O harder then the Rocks, more mercileſſe
Then the wilde evening Woolf.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Mother do not die,
For heavens ſake helpe my Mother; look up
And ye ſhall ſee me dance, and then the Gentleman
Will ſure beſtow a piece of bread upon us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Look here thou Iron-hearted man. upon
A palre of piercing miſeries.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A Scoene of mirth;
I am all hard, the heat of luſt which ſtood
To clip revenge, we ſtem a ſtream of blood.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: How do ye Mother?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How doth my Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Very ſick indeed; but I warrant you are more hungry
Then I a great deale, are you not?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh no,
Thou art weake, and famine plaies the Tyrant with thee;
Look here my boy, bite on thy Mothers arme,
The blood will nouriſh thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Will your blood nouriſh me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I pre • hee try.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why ſhould not mine then nouriſh you? 'tis the ſame;
Good Mother eat my arme, bite but a bite,
Truly I ſhall hurt you if I bite yours,
I warrant you'l be better preſently.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I ſhall my Sonne, and ſo ſhalt thou, come neere me,
Let us go hand in hand to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Oh mother, ſomething pinch'd my very heart,
And I ſhall die, my dear, dear mother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Art thou gone my Sonne?
My ſoule ſhall overtake thee: oh friendly death
That gav'ſt that gripe, ſure when thou kill'ſt the guilty,
Frowns curle thy angry forehead; but when thou ſteal'ſt
Towards innocence, (their pale fears to beguile)
Thou deck'ſt thy lean face with a lovely ſmile.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My Lord recover'd by the valiant King!
In all his battels he is fortunate,
And now tdey ſhall have meate; ha! meat ſaid I?
I have made them worms meat;
Oh what a talking is within me! if I ſtay,
The building ſure will cruſh me, i'le ha • to' • h Court,
My Lord here intimates the Kings obſervance of me,
I muſt hence; oh gnilt, thou draw'ſt deaths image horrid,
When we begin to like our ills, how ſweet a face hath ſin!
Which but paſt by, a cheater ſhe appears,
Joyes are her promiſe, but ſhe paies us fears.

div.stage: Enter Hubert, Queen, and Matilda, a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Your care in the conveyance of Matilda
To this appoited place, the King ſhall recompence,
With-draw your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I ſhall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Matilda, where's that ſpirit that kept thy vertue
Valiant and bold •

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If vertue ſo ill pay us,
Who would be vertuous?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Vertue! pale poverty
Reproach, diſaſter, ſhame ſits on her forehead,
Deſpiſings fill her ſleep • , ill 〈…〉
Meet her at every turne, tears are her triumphs,
Her drink affliction, Calumny attends her,
The unclean tongue of ſlaunder daily licks her
Out of her faſhion; but if you be Kings Johns friend—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh ſtrong temptation.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Matilda—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You may like
A nimble wind, play on the ruſlling boſome
Of that phantaſtick wood, the world; your ſleeps a paradice
hung round with glittering dreames, then your diſſemblings
〈…〉 call'd dev • tions, your rigged 〈◊〉 hypocriſie
Religions holy heats, mirth dee •• the Court d • i • s,
The wanton minutes glide juſt like a ſtreame,
That clips the boſome of a wealthy meade,
Till't get it great with child, a ſweet green blaſſing.
Conſider, 'tis the King.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I, I, the King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Truſt not this tempter, luſts irreligious linguiſt,
Remember vertue is a holy flame,
A ſacred inclination of the ſoul
To all things honeſt.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I can reſiſt no longer,
Oh Hubert, you are a victorious tempter.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Can this be poſſible?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Forget not, at the beginning
Of this ſweet race, honour hold out for you
A golden Garland.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh remember,
At the end of chaſtities white race, an Angell
Holds in his hand (ſhot through a ſilver Cloud,)
A Crown for Conquerers.

sp.speaker: Hub
sp.l: Will ye looſe the pleaſure that—

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I, I, thoſe pleaſures Hubert, there is a voyce
Of fleſh and frailty in me, that ſtill cryes,
Matilda take thoſe pleaſures, and I am now
The Kings for ever.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Let the Queen then cut from earth
Such a diſſembler.

div.stage: Offers violence to Matil. Hubert ſtayes her.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Nay but you ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Shame and death dwell
With a goodneſſe ſo ſhort-ſi • 'd, thou hanſome hypocrite,
Thou faith-defrauder, a religious qualme
