Croſſing the ſtomack of a ſeeming Saint,
Which falls ſtraight into humoor, all thy devotions
Prove now but well-clad cheaters of Times Charity,
Thy griefs, and ſighs, are but ſins crafty games,
Their ſoon ſp • nt flaſhes play like holy flames.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo: to ſome remote place, ſhut
from the danger of the angry Queen i'le carry you,
And thither bring the King.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I long to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hubert, wilt thou play the Court Camclion,
The perſum'd Pander.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes marry will I, Panders have need of perfumes.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh merry ſinne!
We ſmile towards Hell, but howl when we are in,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Name but the place Madam, and religiouſly I vow,
By th'unſtain'd honour of my Name and Hou • e,
By the white reputation of a Gentleman,
And as I wiſh for after happineſſe, my care
Sha • l I ſee it inſtantly in execution.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My Couſen Bruce, Earl Richmond, with the convoy,
The King diſcomfited, they would madly have carried me
To Dunmow Abbey in fruitfull Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: S •• oot a thouſand Kings
could not thence recover ye, but name the place
Whither I ſhall carry you, good Madam whither?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good Hubert thither.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What to a Monaſtory?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Call her diſſembling,
No •• nne good heaven, for ſhe is ſtill a Saint.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Upon my knee I begge it, and every day
When I ſhall drop a Bead, I'le ſtrongly pray
That you may find a bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hark Hubert.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: There is ſomething telis me there is honour in it,
To grant her good requeſt.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Mark how your Oath ran,
By the honour of your Houſe,
By the white reputation of a Gentleman.
And as you wiſh for after happineſſe.
You'd put my wiſh in ſpeedy execution.
Oh Hubert mark, he his houſe pulls down,
That wounds his honour, though to pleaſe a Crown,
By Heraul'ds he's a Gentleman maintain'd,
Whoſe reputations whiteneſſe ſtands unſtain'd,
And he in after happineſſe ſtands high,
That dares not with a ſinne by ſoveraignty.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Excellent Oratory!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hubert, for truths ſake.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh Hubert, for the glorious Crown of chaſtity,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: For the victorious Palme of Wedlock faith,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: By the immaculate ſouls of holy Maids,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: And by the unſtain'd truth of honeſt wives,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: By the tears of Virgins,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: By the truth of vertue,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh now to honour Hubert give thy name,
Sweet blooming vertue knows no bluſh of ſhame.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: The rareneſſe of your ſouls has raviſh'd me,
Wee'l change our courſe, ſteere through bridge, and ſo
For Eſſex and for Dunmow, victorious Maid,
Rhetorick is poor in thy praiſe, whom a King,
Nor ſoveraignty, (the ſoul of womens longings,)
Cannot corrupt!—Oh women! Men-ſubduers!
Natures extreames! no meane is to be had;
Excellent Good, or infinitely bad!

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Moſt noble Hubert.

div.stage: Enter King, Fitzwater, Cheſter and Oxford.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Twas well yet that the trick has catch'd this old one,
Where are the reſt?

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Richmond is gone for France,
Leiſter eſcap'd to Winſor.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How I thirſt
To make mine arms walthy with ſweet Matilda.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Oh if a Fathers prayers, an old mans tears,
An injur'd old mans tears, were ever prevalent,
Good heaven keep my Girle a Chriſtall Fort,
Firme and unvuanquiſh'd.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hnbert my friend now has her:
Will it pleaſe the mighty Emporor of the Barrons,
The King may kiſſe Matilda, ſhe will be here preſently,
Then • ſhall the great Fitzwater ſit in ſtate,
And ſee Matilda and the poor King dallie,
And teach the winds to wanton; Hubert now has her,
The faithful'ſt of my friends, from contrari • ties
We will produce ſoft pleaſures, ſweet perfections;
Sir • ah, Cheſter ſhall tell me when ſhe then frowns, and
Wee'l Court her checks into a comely ſmile;
If ſhe but raiſe that milkie hill, her breaſt,
With reſpirations, Oxford ſhall ſwear
it is a ſigh, and I will ſeem to chide
His raſhneſſe, and proteſt love rais'd that gale,
Juſt as her heart for my heart had ſet ſale.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Heare heaven!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Cheſter ſhall watch her when ſhe weeps, and tell me
They are Matilda', tears, when I will preſently
With a lovers pleaſing fervency, proteſt
They are Pearls, by paſſion forc'd from Cupids Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: But what ſhall Hubert do,
Your boſome friend?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: He ſhall with pretty thwarting paſſages
(To pleaſe Matilda,) ſeeme to make me angry,
And tell me'tis impoſſible now t'obtain her;
Whereupon (impatient, to illuſtrate love
With a new paſſion) oh how I will rave!
Miſuſe him ſtrangely, and cloſe up the ſweet Sco • ne
Upon Matilda's lip.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Letters from th'Earl Hubert ſir,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: His name but now,
(Like a beloved paſſenger,) took leave
Of my unwilling lips, he waits directions
Concerning her from me, good Cheſter read it,
I cannot read and rejoyce too, Fitzwater
Liſten, and rave.

div.p: Letter. May it pleaſe your excellent Majeſtie, it hath, pleas'd heaven ſo throughly to captivate my reaſon by the potent pleadings of your vertuous Queene, and unmatch'd Matilda, that I hold it now impoſſible for your Majeſtie ever to obtain her.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: That laſt was muſick.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Nay kill us all, kill us all; will ye read on ſir?

body.head: Let.
body.p:
Briefly, by that time theſe Letters kiſſe your Royall hands,
ſhe will be cloyſterd up in Dunmow Abbey, and end her dayes a Veſtall, wheither I could not chooſe but convey her, being thereunto forcibly charmed by her teares and entreaties, and eſpecially forc'd by a ſecret command from heaven to mine owne conſcience; I remaine your most excellent Majeſties tranſgreſſing ſervant

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Moſt excellent villaine!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Obſerve King John, e're heaven will vertue faile,
Contrary meanes, all winds ſhall ſill her ſaile.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: How like a Hare, the Greyhounds chaps ſtill at her,
Yet ſtill ſhe ſcapes! the King is full of tempeſt.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: She's gone for ever.
Oh Hubert let us never meet again,
Never more meet; Fitzwater fetch herbut back,
As from the firſt, ſo from this Iſabell
Wee'l be divorc'd, marry and ſet Matilda
I'th regall Chaire, the Kings admired Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: But will ye ſay and do ſir?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yet there is hope; now by my Crown I will,
We ſhall be Sonne and Father, thou and I
Will walke upon our Pallace battlements,
And thou ſhalt carty up a covetous eye,
And thou ſhalt caſt that covetous eye about
The fair, delightful village-ſpotted valleyes,
Thou ſhalt ſtand ſtill, and think, and recollect
The troubl'd longings of thy large deſires,
And whatſoever thou ſhalt aske the King,
(Of all thou ſee'ſt) the King ſhall give it thee.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, let one one ride before, and certifie
That we are comming.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Cheſter, put on wings:
Thou good old man, the bird that croak'd now ſings.

div.head: Actus 5. Scoena 1.
div.stage: Enter King and Fitzwater, Oxford meeting them.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: THeſe are the Abby walls, Oxford what news?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Matilda is afraid to venture forth,
But on yon battlements it was her promiſe,
With the Lady Abbeſs to appear—and ſee ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Give us leave • Oh were that habite
Not ſo unkind, a foe to faire increaſe,
I'de call it then celeſtiall, and ſwear.
A bright ſtar mov'd in that immaculate ſpheare:
Matilda! Miſtreſſe of many Graces!
And lovely as the bluſh that breaks the day!
Caſt thy commanding eyes upon a King,
Whom love hath made a begger;

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Why hunts the King
With ſuch a violent pourſuit, a chaſte Dove,
That hath given up her name to heaven, and ſtands
White as her ſpotleſſe veſture.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Lady Abbeſſe,
Pray give me leave, and hearken my Matilda,
I bring thee gol • n news my Girle, we have caſt
An ill-becomming Calumnie upon
The Kings love all this while; for he proteſt •
To be divorc'd from Iſabell the Queene,
And by marriage ſet thee in his B • d,
A plant to ſpring and proſper; women naturally
Do aflect ſoveraignty; wilt thou runne retrograde
In 〈◊〉 faire Zodiack? though all wayes yet
Have fail'd, this will take I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Who hath taught my Father
To tum Apoſtate to that integrity
Slept in his noble breaſt? through a divorce
I run to golden ruine; the King marry me?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And make thee Queen of him, and two large Kingdoms,
The Chriſtian world when they ſhall hear, ſhall wonder,
And magnifie in their abundant praiſes,
The glory of our Marriage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, here I can call neceſſity,
Excellent Pyhſick for a vaſt deſire,
Our wants are holy waters, caſt on luſt's fire.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Oh brave, brave Girle!
That I had thee here to buſs thee,
Her very breath did ſmell of heaven.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Matilda!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I have found thee Gold my Girle,
Theſe are glorious wreſtlings,
Celeſtial ſtruglings; paſſion of me, that joy
Should carry Aprill eyes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Matilda, Look upon thy ſoveraigne courting,
Thy cruelty with a paire of wooing eyes,
Labouring for mercy.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: No, no, Matilda, look upon thy ſoveraigne,
Thy chaſtity with tempting wanton eyes,
Labouring in luſt.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou man of rude defects, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Thou man of wilde deſires, let me alone.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Tut, tut, I know whoſe Cauſe I have in hand,
And neither ha's nor hems can fright plain Robin,
The wound that fooliſh love-Boy there (what call ye him?)
Had ſtruck your heart with, becauſe your ſmooth tongue,
You could not come to ſupple it, as the Dog does his foot,
With fair fine words you could lick me, and then
Lift me to ſtroak it, and heale it by Atturney,
He ſteers not ſteddy thae delights to roame,
Craft ſets out ſwift, but ever comes ſhort home:
I tell ye truth I.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Abbeſſe, deliver up Mattlda,
Or with an Army fill'd with Ruffians, Ra • iſhers,
The very Sonnes of darkneſſe, we will levell
This building to the bottome.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: We know the King,
(Being reconcil'd unto his mother Church,)
• annot conceive ſuch out-rage.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Now ye ſtamp, do ye.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Father farewell, and to my Lord my King,
And good your Maieſtie be • l • as'd to remember,
How excellently-admirable your Crown
Will then become ye, when you ſhall • aſt off
The habite of your paſſions, I will pray for you ſir,
And if't be poſſible with prayers and teares,
Quench your de • res, and fortifie my feares.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: A Fathers bleſſing, like a welcome cloud
With child of friendly ſhowers, hover o're thy goodneſſe,
And keep it evergreen—; ſhe is gone ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Go thou and runne into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Ha, ha, So the great Emperor of the Ba • rons,
As you cal'd him,
May come out aagin i'th guts of a poor John:
No, no, I will live and laugh, you would have made her
The miſtreſſe of the King, and ſhe is married
To • he Kings Maſter, oh to the nobleſt King
Poore ſupplicant ever kneel'd to, to your King,
And her King, and to my King ſhe's married;
Oh married, married, let the Satyrs dance it,
The ſweet Birds ſing it, let the winds be wanton,
And as they ſoftly with an evening whiſper,
Steal through the curl'd locks of the lofty woods,
Let them in their ſweet language ſeem to ſay,
This, this was chaſte Matilda's Marriage day.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: It reſolv'd irrevocable; who waits?

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Have an eye apon that Fox; where's our Confeſſor?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Attending ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Your ear—do this,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And hark you, without all expoſtulation, ſpeedily
Make Brand the Inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I ſhall not fail ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: All my blood turns, ſhe is now paſt all recovery;
Oh day draw in thy light, Time do not keep
This Deed for ſtory; Memory fall aſleep
In black oblivions Cavern; let this day
Still skip the Kalend, and be wip'd away
From all diſcourſe; oh let no chaſte Maid.
(Remembring how Matilda was betray'd,)
With bitter teares, curſe the too cruell King;
No Satyr dance this day, no ſweet bird ſing,
But let the Raven and Screcth. Owl cry,
Matilda the chaſte Maid, muſt this day dye.

div.stage: Enter Brand and the Abbeſſe reading a Letter.

body.head: Lett.
body.p: Theſe are to giye you to underſtund, that inſtantly, and without any the leaſt expoſtulation, you ſee convey'n into the outward Garden adjoyning to the Abby, your new Votary Matilda, that the bearer (this Gentleman) may without the leaſt interception, have freedome of acceſſe unto her; let this from me be your ſafety, and forget not, the wills of Princes are indiſputable—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: No, no, no cloud of niceneſs, order, or regularity,
Muſt intercept this Mandate; Sir, the Kings will,
The Confeſſors advertizement, and your hopes,
Shall meet this minute; but vertue is I hope
The Rudder of your voyage.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I tell you Madam, 'tis unſpotted truth,
The King is chang'd ſo excellent, ſuch a lover
Now of Matilda's noble conſtancy,
That therefore as his (Confeſſor there certifies,)
Your duty is expected
To work my admittance to her, which is onely
To let her know, how heartily his Majeſtie
Admires and commends her.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Tis a joyful hearing,
See where ſhe walks, ſouls • o heavenly ſimple,
It ſeems the Court digeſts not, and (being cloy'd,)
Commends them to the Cloyſter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And ſhe be ſo ſimple,
She's the fitter for the Saints, things I near think of,
Unleſſe to ſtuffe our ſimilies—excellent Lady.
There's ſuch a deale of heaven in her face,
It makes my black ſoul tremble—excellent Lady,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your will ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: To let you underſtand the will of him,
Whoſe will the will of heaven hath new made;
Thus ſaid King John in briefe, tell that ſweet Saint,
(And there he wept as I do at the thought on't)
The immaculate Miſtreſſe of my dear devotions.
The King by this (with her eye not unacquainted)
Commends to her his hate of all that love,
The feavor of his blood contaminated:
Oh tell her (and he ſigh'd there bitterly)
That as I was her tempter, I am now
Mine own deſpiſer; as mine own deſpiſer,
I will remain her vertues ſtrong admirer;
And there juſt thus he kiſt it—; if't chance, quoth he,
Her gentle lip return the Kings chaſte meaning,
Mark but which place of this (then happy (Glove
Receives that heavenly print, and bring it back,
That my lips there (like a paire of willing Pilgrims)
May pay my hearts devotions. This was all,
And this, his Glove, the Token.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Excellence Change!
Heaven now hath heard my praiers, return his goodneſſe;
I am ſorry thou haſt kiſt the Glove before me,
For feare thy lips have lay'n where the Kings did,
And coſen'd mine of that grace fell from them,
When he ſpake things thus good, Give me the Glove.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Ha: He looks towards the Garden door, and whilſt ſhe turns her ſelf that way, he changes the Glove, and gives her the other poyſon'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thy looks made me beleeve, that ſome were coming.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No Madam, I have coſen'd you, twas but the wind.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No wind ſhall keep my duty from his Majeſtie
With my obſervance; ſay thus, I return'd
My love of his great goodneſſe; and if he aske thee
How I receiv'd the news of his rare change,
Say, as a teeming ſoyle after a drought,
Welcomes a wiſh'd for ſhower: what a ſtrange ſent
Strongly beats up into my braines, while I hold this Glove
So neer my breaſt! thou art not honeſt ſure?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Neer death we propheſie, and 'tis ſo ſure,
You cannot breath three minutes.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Tis neatly don, and there's no dallying,
I know 'tis ſtrong and ſwift, as by a Glove
You were carryed from your Fathers to this Cloyſter,
So by a Glove you are from this Cloyſter ſent
To the chaſte Court of Saints.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Heaven! is this right?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No, 'twas a left-handed Glove, look ye,
I kiſt the right and coſen'd you,
So that a ſiniſter act with a left-handed Glove, very prettily
Imports a wittyneſſe in wickedneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thou art a merry murderer, the King was wont
To call me friend; oh if he beſtowes
On's friends ſuch guifts, what ſends he to his foes?
Uncharitable love-token; oh what harſh hand
Temperd this dram of death.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I could do't no better.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh cozening Crocadile, that with thy tears couldſt take me •
How wilt thou howſe
When thou and I meet next? when I ſhall ſit
Above my ſufferings, then will my blood be
A cloud betwixt eternity and thee.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Clouds? yes, much clouds.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There was the laſt call; to the King, commend me,
And tell him, when in ſtories he ſhall ſtand,
When men ſhall read the Conquerors great name,
Voluptuous Ruſus, that unkind brother Beaucla • k,
Comely King Steven, Henry the Wedlock-breaker,
And Lyon-hearted Richard; when they come
unto his name, with ſighs it ſhall be ſaid,
This was King John—the murderer of a Maid;
Oh tell him I am paſt his ſtrong temptations,
And though wild burning back'd his hot deſire,
Like perfect Gold I did out-live the fire.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: She's dead and I muſt ſhift for one,
I heare ſome trampling,
What's he has leap'd the Garden walls? has awenching look,
And ſhould be a good Vaulter, guilty knaves make excellent
Eves droppers, and I love to ſound ſtrange boſomes, I will lye
To ſee and heare, and yet not heard nor ſeen,

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Here rumour gives, my couſin, chaſte Matilda
To live a Votary: ha! on the ground!
Murder'd moſt certainly, and ſo warme, that yet
The murderer at my approach, may lurk
About the Garden, for through the Abbey tis
Impoſſible to paſſe; oh my griev'd blood,
Who made it ſo unfortunate to be good.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He mumbles ſomething to himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: This parallels my Mother and my Brother:
Ha! ſomething ſti • s i'th Grove, paſſion I know thee not,
With a new art we muſt catch old Blood-hounds: well,
Although I am the Kings well-wiſhing friend,
And have rais'd forces for his part at Winſor,
Yet with my heart I am glad, a friendly hand
Hath ma le thee happy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: S'foot this is one of our ſide,
But it ſeems he knows not twas the Kings injunction.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Now buſineſſe will be minded, ſtate affairs,
With vigilance effected, which before
Were ſo intangled in your hair forſooth,
Suiters could find no end of their beginnings.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: By this light I have done a good deed.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Thou honeſt ſoul,
That (by the heat of thy happy hany-work,)
Canſt not I am ſure but be in hearing; If
My irregular ſtart (upon private neceſſity)
Frighted thee off, be not aſham'd to let
Thy unknown friend poſſeſſe thee.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Oh braze young ſpark.

sp.speaker: Y. Eru.
sp.l: Or if thy modeſty muſt keep thee off,
So well I love thy work (and as I the Kingdom)
Let this Purſe of Gold, this Diamond faſten'd to't,
Tell thee thy friend was here, if thoul'dſt know him,
He is a kinſman to the Earl of Cheſter;
And becauſe thou ſhalt not doubt thy friends fair meanings,
I will return the way I came, although
With danger to my perſon.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Here is one ſir, wiſhes better to his friends.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: One that will take your honoorable Purſe,
And yet paſſe quit at the Common Law.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Wert thou the expert Maſter of this peece.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You being kinſman to my Lord and Maſter,
(Who ever hated this blood;) I dare tell you,
I practi • 'd firſt a buſineſſe late at Winſor,
Upon a Mother and her Sonne—

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Hold heart, old Bruces Lady,
And the brat her Sonne?
Wer't thou the happy inſtrument
To cut theſe Houſes down? didſt thou do that?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It would deſerve (well priz'd) another Purſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Gold muſt not part us, didſt do't?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Both that and this, by this ſtand ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Sonne of the Devill have I ſound thee?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sure he knows me.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Fool, doſt thou draw a ſword;
What a loud lye thou doſt give heaven, to think
A ſword can ſhield the guilty, look here villaine
Upon my horrid point, where death in tempeſt
And whirle-winds, ſtares upon thee, thou murderer:
Of my Mother, Brother, and my Kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: S'root here was a Purſe wi • h a bob at the end ont,
Pray take your Purſe againe.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Toad, I will take thy heart firſt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I deny nothing then,
Reſolution crowns my craft; for thoſe at Winſor,
(Let me free the King) I • ami •• 'd them, becauſe
Your Mother was too coy, you may gueſs the reſt;
For this it was King Johns in junction,
And I have done it daintily by this light.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: By darkneſſe and • er Angels,
Thy near kinſmen,
Thou ſhalt not live five minutes for't.

div.stage:
They fight, Bran •
falls, young Bruce keeps him down.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O ſir, what mean ye?

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: To aske thee for a Mother, a ſweet Brother,
A chaſte kinſwoman; oh that thou couldſt be
Ten daies a dying; Slave! i'le ſtick thy Trunck
So thick with wounds, it ſhall appear a Book
Full of red Letters,
Characters of thy cruelty

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: This is no bleeding moneth fir.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Thon lyeſt, look yonder;
There lyes mine Almanack, a celeſtiall body,
Whoſe revolution, period, pale aſpect,
All tell me'tis high time that thou ſhouldſt bleed.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Thy veines are all corruption,
Toads belch not fouler;
And ſhould thy Trunck be thrown upon a dunghill,
(As it deſerves no better buriall)
The ſent would poyſon ſwine, the very dogs
And every Raven that ſhould 〈◊〉 upon't,
Would ſeek forſaken Deſerts, and there die
Full of infection.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Oh that laſt has finiſh't me,
And where I go I know not, a bloody Cloud
Hath hid heaven from me like a purple ſhrowd.

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: Feaſt thou the Crows,
This body i'le convey to Winſor, where my Mother,
And my ſweet murther'd Brother, wee'l expoſe
(As ſpurs of righteous vengeance) to all eyes;
Conſcience, and Blood, are ſtrong inceſſant cryes.

div.stage: Exit. Enter King and Lords below, old Bruce, Leiſter Oxford and Fitzwater above. Charge.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You Sonnes of death and diſobedience;
Why is the King kept out?

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: You ſhall know ſir;
Is't not enough the whole Lands Liberties
Lye yet a gaſping by your head ſtrong paſſions,
Wounded by your neglect, but through blood
D' • e chaſe your vaſt deſires, my Wife and Sonne ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A game as we are Prince, in our Royall word,
The villaine paſt our precept.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: As you paſt heavens
In your bloody maſquing night at Baynards Caſtle,
When all the floores, and the white walls wore bloody
Deep crimſon bluſhes, to behold a Prince
In blood purſue his paſſions.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bar'd out and brav'd,
You bate and chafe a Lyon; bring old Fitzwater,
Thou Bruce and grumbling Leiſter, either ſpeedily
Give up the Caſtle, and upon your knees
Fall to the mercy you have ſcorn'd, or here
Before a paire of minutes paſſe, the ſword
Of incens'd juſtice ſhall even in your eyes,
Leave this old Rebell headleſſe.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Now by the blood
I loſt in holy Paleſtine with Richard,
Oh that right reall Souldier! King John I ſweare,
That foul-word Rebel ha • unrivited
Is it to take truths part to be a Rebel?
To eaſe my groaning Country, is that Rebellion?
To preſerve the unſtain'd honour of a Maid,
(And that maid my daughter) to preſerve your glory,
That you ſtand not branded in our Chronicles,
By the black name of Wedlock-breaker; is this
(Good, heaven!) is this Rebellion? Come, come, the Axe;
Oh that wrong'd ſoul to death ſo falſely given,
Flies ſweetly ſinging her own truth to heaven.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: Stand on your guard-ſir,
Young Bruce with twenty thouſand
Strong able men from Cambridge and Eſſex,
With a ſpeedy march, and with as dreadful threatnings,
Comes thundering towards Winſor, all his Enſigns
Crimſon and black, which in their want • n wavings,
Cry to the frighted Country (as he marches)
Nothing but blood and d • ath.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: Oh noble Sonne of a murpered M • ther.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Honourable young man.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Draw up our forces like a pair of angry winds,
That have got a hollow Cloud with child of tempeſts,
Wee'l make the valleyes tremble.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Reſiſt now ſir,

Or the whole Kingdome trembles,
• ewis the Dolphines
By th'politique working of ingenius Richmond,
(Who was ſent for him) with ſix hundred ſayle,
And fourſcore Flat-boats is let in at Dover,
Subduing as they march, and the Towns willingly

Givin •
• hem way; they have reach'd Rocheſter,
And if a ſpeedy ſwift prevention meet not,
They will for London certainly.

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Now John thy Crown ſits quivering.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: Theſe here ſo reſolute—

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: Youug Bruce ſo potent—

sp.speaker: Ox • .
sp.l: And which ſtrikes deepe, a factious forraigne foot
Upon our earth, 'tis a dangerous triplcity,
So that our Forces were they three times trebl'd,
(Diſtracted with a diviſion thus trianguler)
Cannot promiſe ſafety.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Take it not Time, for now
The goodlieſt Oak in the whole wood muſt bow.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Oh that was very well ſaid ſir, nor ſhall ye bow,
But unto heaven and vertue, for Kings have boaſted
To be her ſervants; oh in this tempeſt ſir,
Give her the helme, good brother Bruce, the King
Has faithfully acquitted him of the bloods
Of your Wife and Sonne,; Leiſter, the King now looks
Upon his paſſions with a diſpleaſed eye,
Truſt to our faiths ſir, give the Land her Liberties,
And do but look upon my poor Matilda.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: With Kingly chaſte eyes; and a holy ſoul;
My brother ſhall command his Sonne to obedience,
Leiſter and he ſhall give ye up the Caſtle,
We will call Richmond with his powers from Lewis,
We will be all one ſoule againe, and force
The skipping French to put to Sea again,
And you ſhall ſtand a King then abſolute;
Good brother Leiſter, ſir upon my knee,
I urge your goodneſſe now; ſhall we ſtill ſtand
And chaine our freedomes to a forraign hand?
When we ſhun ſeen Rocks, then we ſafely ſayle;
Good, good, King John, let the old man prevaile.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh Cheſter run to Dunmow, and if Brand yet
Have kept his hand whi • e, bid that Brand forbear,
For feare of burning everlaſtingly.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: I ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Mowbray, with the bendings of the King,
Go meet that angry young man Bruce, and tell him,
Here's now no uſe for ſteele.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: 'Twill be good news ſir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Meet us at leaſt (you ſtubborn men,)
In our facile affections:
Why ſend ye not for Richmond? muſt we bend, and
And beſeech too?

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Paſſe but your Royal promiſe
In the words of a King, to performe what
Y'are fled from, the wind not with more ſwiftneſſe,
Shall fly to play with Richmonds lofty Plume,
Then ſhall be ſhown in his repeale.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Tis granted upon our Kingly word—that time in me,
ſhall read that Giants force neceſſity!

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: With all ſubmiſſive reverence we deſcend,
And kiſſe your Highneſſe hand.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Right happy day,
My Girle is ſafe, and all clouds blown away.

div.stage: Hoboyes ſound, whilſt the Barrons deſcend, each on his knee kiſſing the Kings hand, both Parties joyfully embrace; ſuddenly the Hoboyes ceaſe and a ſad Muſick of Flutes heard. Enter to the King and Lords, the Lady Abbeſs, Uſhering Matilda's Herſe, born by Virgins, this Motto faſmed unto it—To Piety and Chaſtity. The Body of Matilda lying on the Herſe, and attended by the Queene, bearing in her hand a Garland, compos'd of Roſes and Lillies; after her, young Bruce, Hubert, Cheſter, and other Gentlemen, all in mourning habites.

lg.l: LOoke what Death hath done! here laid
(In one) a Martyr, and a Maid.
Angels Crown Thoſe with juſt applauſe.
Dye in defence of Vertues Lawes.

lg.head: Chorus
lg.l: Such was her cauſe! Death! boaſt not of thy hands •
Cruelty, ſince the uanquiſh'd victor ſtands.
Her Chaſtity, to Time ſhall laſt
Like Laurel, which no lightning can blast.
Sweet Maids, with Roſes deck her Herſe,
Whoſe Vertue ſtands above the reach of Verſe.

lg.head: Chorus
lg.l: Heaven hath her pure part, whil'ſt on Earth, • her Name
Moves in the Spheare of areſulgent Fame.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hubert interpret this Apparition.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Behold ſir,
A fad writ Tragedy ſo ferlingly,
Languag'd, and caſt, with ſuch a crafty cruelty,
Contriv'd and acted, that wild Savages,
Satyrs, and the rude rabble of the Woods,
Would weep to lay their ears to, and (admiring
To ſee themſelves out done) they would conceive
Their wildneſſe, mildneſs to this deed, and call
Men more then Savage, themſelves rationall;
And thou Fitzwater, reflect upon thy name,
And turn the ſonne of tears, oh forget
That Cupid ever ſpent a dart upon thee,
That Hymen ever coupled thee, or that ever
The haſty, happy, willing meſſenger,
Told thee thou hadſt a Daughter; oh look here,
Look here King John, and with a tembling eye,
Read your ſad act, Matilda's Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Matilda!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: By the labouring ſoul of a much injur'd man,
It is my childe Matilda.

sp.speaker: Qu
sp.l: Oh cruell King, go • ate thy bloody eye
With thy black command, which there lyes executed.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: Sweet Neece,

sp.speaker: Leiſ.
sp.l: Chaſte ſoule,

sp.speaker: Y. Bru.
sp.l: King, go and read thy cruelty.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Do I ſtirre Cheſter?
Good Oxford, do I move? ſtand I not ſtill
To watch the when the griev'd friends of dead Matilda,
Will with a thouſand ſtabs turn me to duſt?
That in a thouſand prayes they may be happy;
Wil no one do't? then give a mourner room,
A man of tears; oh immaculate Matilda,
Theſe ſheed but ſayling heat drops, miſſing ſhowers,
The faint dews of a doubtful April-morning;
But from mine eyes, ſhip-ſincking Ca • aracts,
Whold clouds of waters, wealthy exhalations
Shall fall into the Sea of my affliction,
Till it amaze the Mourners.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Unmatch'd Matilda,
Celeſtiall Souldier that keep'ſt a Fort of Chaſtity
'Gainſt all temptations.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Not to be a Queene
Would ſhe break her chaſte vow, truth crowns your reed,
Unmatch'd Matilda was her name indeed.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh take into your ſpirit-piercing praiſe,
My Scoene of ſorrow; I have wel-clad woes,
Pathetick epethites to illuſtrate paſſion,
And ſteale true teares ſo ſweetly from all theſe,
'tſhall touch the ſoule, and at one pierce and pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: What will he doe?

div.stage: The Ki. takes the Gar and from the Queen, and peruſes the Motto of the Herſe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: To Prety and Purity, and Lillies mixt with Roſes.
How well you have apparell'd woe, this pendant
To Piety and Purity directed,
Inſinuates a chaſte ſoule in a clean body:
Vertues white Virgin, Chaſtities red Martyr,
Suffer me then with this well-ſuited wreath,
To make our griefs ingenious, let all be dumb,
Whilſt the King ſpeaks her Epicedium.

sp.speaker: Cheſ.
sp.l: His very ſoul ſpeaks ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: And it becomes him ſweetly.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hail Maid and Marty! loe on thy breaſt,
Devotions Alter, chaſte truths cheſt,
I offer (as my guilt impoſes)
Thy merrits Laurel, Lillies and Roſes,
Lillies, intimating plaine,
Thy immaculate life ſtuck with no ſtaine;
Roſes red, and ſweet, to tell
How ſweet red ſacrifices ſmell;
sp.stage: Sets the Garland on her breaſt.
sp.l: Hang round then as you walk about this Herſe,
The ſongs of holy hearts, ſweet, vertuous verſe,

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Bring Perſian ſilks to deck her Monument,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Arabian ſpices quick'ning by their ſent.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Numidian Marble to preſerve her praiſe,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Corinthian Ivory her ſweet ſhape to raiſe.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: And write in gold upon it, in this breſt,
Virtue ſat Miſtreſſe paſſion but a gueſt;

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Virtue is ſweet, and ſince griefs bitter be.
Strew her with Roſes, and give Rue to me.

sp.speaker: Ol. Bru.
sp.l: My noble Brother, I have loſt a Wife and Son,
You a ſweet Daughter, look on the Kings penitence,
His promiſe for the Kindomes peace, perfer
A publique benefit. When it ſhall pleaſe,
Let heaven queſtion him, let us ſecure,
And quit the Land of Lewis.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Do any thing,
Do all things that are honourable, and the great King,
Make you a good King ſir; and when your ſoul.
Shall at any time reflect upon your follies,
Good King John weep, weep very heartily,
It will become you ſweetly, at your eyes
Your ſin ſtole in, there pay your ſacrifie.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Back unto Dunmow Abby, where wee'l pay
To ſweet Matilda's memory and her ſufferings,
A monthly obſequie, which (ſweetned by
The wealthy woes of a tear-troubl'd eye)
Shall by thoſe ſharp afflictions of my face,
Court Mercy, and make Grief 〈…〉
Let my wil'd errors, tell to time this truth;
Wh • l'ſt paſſion holds the Helm, Reaſon and Honour.
Do ſuffer wrack; but they ſaile ſafe, and cleer,
Who conſtantly by Virtues Compaſſe ſteer.

lg.l: MAtilda! Now goe take thy Bed,
In the darke dwellings of the dead.
And riſe in the great Waking-day,
Sweet as Incenſe, freſh as May.
Reſt thou chaſte ſoule, (fixt in thy proper ſpheare,)
Amongſt heauens faire Ones; All are fair ones there.

lg.head: Cho.
lg.l: Reſt there chaſte ſoul, whilſt we (here troubl'd) ſay,
Time gives us Griefs, Death takes our joyes away.
